• The transport properties of nonlinear non-equilibrium dynamical systems, particularly chaotic ratchet systems, are not well-understood.
• Mateos conjectured a connection between current reversal and bifurcation from chaotic to periodic behavior, but this was later argued against by Barbi and Salerno.
• The current in a chaotic ratchet depends significantly on the details of the initial ensemble, and it is important to discard transients when quantifying the current.
• While Mateos's conjecture is not universally valid, a generalized version is proposed: bifurcations in the trajectory dynamics are associated with abrupt changes in the current.
• The dependence of the current on the ensemble characteristics is most critical near certain bifurcation points.
• Not all current reversals are associated with bifurcations, nor do all bifurcations lead to current reversals.
• Sudden changes in the current, including but not limited to reversals, are generally associated with bifurcations in the trajectory dynamics.
• The reasons for when the proposed heuristic rules are violated or valid remain open questions.

* Quantum systems can exhibit non-classical correlations, which can be classified into three types: non-separability, EPR-steerability, and Bell-nonlocality. EPR-steerability is the only way to verify entanglement if one of the parties or their detectors cannot be trusted.
* The authors investigate the EPR-steerability of two-qubit states with maximally mixed marginals, known as T-states. They construct a deterministic local hidden state (LHS) model that describes the measurement correlations for a large class of T-states.

* The authors find a remarkable connection between their LHS model and the quantum steering ellipsoid, which is a geometric representation of the set of possible steered states.
* The authors show that their necessary condition for EPR-steerability of T-states, derived from the LHS model, is very close to the sufficient conditions in many regions of the parameter space.
* The authors discuss the possibility of generalizing their results to arbitrary two-qubit states and to the case where Alice is allowed to perform positive operator-valued measurements (POVMs) instead of just projective measurements.
* The authors acknowledge the contributions of David Jennings and the support from various funding agencies for this work.

• Cataclysmic variables (CVs) are short-period binaries containing a white dwarf primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary. The main features of the orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors are the lack of systems in the 2-3 hour period range (the period gap) and the sharp cut-off of the distribution at around 77 minutes.

• Theoretical models have been unable to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cut-off and the observed shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cut-off. The orbital period evolution reflects the radius evolution of the mass donor, which is governed by two competing effects: mass transfer and thermal relaxation.

• The authors investigate ways to increase the period minimum by increasing the mass transfer rate and ways to "hide" the spike by introducing a spread of minimum period values in the CV population. They consider the effect of a form of consequential angular momentum loss (CAML) and the tidal deformation of the secondary.

• The authors find that even a maximally efficient CAML mechanism cannot increase the bounce period sufficiently, and an implausibly large deformation factor of around 1.18 is needed to obtain a bounce period of 78 minutes. They also consider the possibility that the minimum period is an age limit rather than a period bounce.

• The authors employ a modified Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to measure the "goodness" of fit of their synthesized model populations against the observed sample. None of their synthesized model populations fits as well as a distribution that is simply flat in orbital period.

• Models designed to "wash out" the period spike by introducing a large spread of the CAML efficiency generally do better than population models based on donor stars that are subject to a large spread of intrinsic deformation factors. Adding newborn CVs with small donor mass to the population makes the period spike more pronounced.

• The authors conclude that the period minimum problem and the period spike problem remain open issues, and it is possible to construct CV model populations where the period spike is washed out sufficiently so that it cannot be ruled out unambiguously on the basis of an objective statistical test against the observed CV period distribution.
</summary>

• The paper introduces a new class of networks called "sequence nets" that are constructed from sequences of letters and fixed rules of connectivity. Threshold nets are a special case of sequence nets, and the paper also discovers two new classes of two-letter sequence nets.

• The paper shows that the structural properties of the new classes of two-letter sequence nets can be analyzed easily, and introduces an ordering in ensembles of sequence nets that is useful in visualizing and studying their various attributes.

• The paper fully classifies three-letter sequence nets, showing that they too can be analyzed simply, and that their diameter grows linearly with the number of letters in the alphabet.

• The paper establishes a mapping between sequence nets and generalized types of threshold nets, where connectivity is decided by the difference in node weights rather than their sum.

• The paper discusses several open questions, such as whether there are further symmetries that can reduce the class of three-letter nets, how to determine which sequences lead to connected nets, and whether such mappings to generalized threshold nets are always possible.

• The paper suggests that realistic diameters might be achieved with a modest expansion of the alphabet, and that the new classes of sequence nets may be a particularly good model for social networks.

• The paper highlights the modularity and compressibility of sequence nets, as well as the ease with which their structural properties can be computed, including the possibility of designing nets with desired attributes.

• The paper introduces a natural ordering of sequence nets based on their alphabetical ordering, which reveals intriguing fractal patterns in the eigenvalues and other structural properties.

• The paper shows that some three-letter sequence nets can be mapped to generalized forms of threshold nets with two thresholds, rather than one.

• The paper concludes by discussing various open problems and directions for future research on sequence nets.
</summary>

• The paper examines the nonlinear current response in one-band and two-band superconductors. In the one-band case, the authors find that strong electron-phonon coupling and impurities can lead to enhanced nonlinearity at both low and high temperatures, which is different from the typical BCS behavior. They provide analytical formulas to capture these strong-coupling effects.

• For two-band superconductors, the authors show that the signatures of the smaller gap band can be observed in the nonlinear coefficients when the bands are nearly decoupled. However, with increased interband coupling or scattering, this signature disappears, and the nonlinearity becomes more monotonic.

• The authors also investigate the effect of impurities in the individual bands and find that impurities in the smaller gap band can reduce the nonlinearity at lower temperatures, while impurities in the larger gap band primarily affect the nonlinearity at higher temperatures.

• The authors provide a detailed prediction for the nonlinear coefficient in the two-band superconductor MgB2, using the parameters from band structure calculations. They find that the nonlinearity is monotonically increasing, in contrast to a previous approximated prediction.

• The authors also find that if the supercurrent samples the c-axis direction in MgB2, the increased anisotropy in the Fermi velocity ratio between the bands would result in a larger nonlinearity.

• Finally, the authors provide simple analytical formulas near the critical temperature that help understand the range of behaviors observed in the numerical calculations, and they await experimental verification of their predictions.
</summary>

</summary>

• The origin of celestial gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) is one of the most important astrophysical phenomena still lacking an explanation. GRBs are powerful flashes of gamma-rays lasting from less than one second to tens of seconds, with an isotropic distribution in the sky.

• Thanks to the BeppoSAX satellite, afterglow emission at lower wavelengths has been discovered, and it is now known that at least long GRBs are at cosmological distances. The most likely candidates for the origin of GRBs are the collapse of a very massive star (hypernova) and the coalescence of one compact binary system.

• Emission of gravitational waves (GWs) is expected to be associated with these events. According to several models, the duration of a GW burst is predicted to be of the order of a few milliseconds for a variety of sources, including the coalescing and merging black holes and/or neutron star binaries.

• The Rome group operates two resonant bar detectors, Explorer and Nautilus, to study the presence of correlations between GRB events detected with BeppoSAX and the output signals from gravitational antennas. The agreement between the values of the simulated input signals and the values calculated using the model shows that the model is correct.

• The data are summarized by an observed average squared energy, which is a random number modeled with a Gaussian probability density function around the expected value in the case of noise alone. The probability inversion is obtained using Bayes theorem.

• The probability density function of the GW amplitude is plotted, and the highest beliefs are for very small values, while values above a certain threshold are practically ruled out. An upper limit for the amplitude of GWs can be provided, such that there is a given probability for the amplitude to be below it.

• The Bayesian approach offers natural ways to present prior-independent results, such as providing the likelihood for each hypothesis under investigation, or publishing the likelihood rescaled to the asymptotic limit where experimental sensitivity is lost completely.

• Using a cross-correlation method applied to the data of Explorer and Nautilus, new experimental upper limits have been determined for the burst intensity causing correlations of GWs with GRBs. The result is also given in terms of scaled likelihoo

<summary>
• The paper discusses the citation distribution of scientific publications, which follows a power-law form. This distribution is a consequence of highly cited papers being more likely to acquire further citations, a process known as preferential attachment.

• The paper proposes a simple model that considers two research areas and the referencing within and across each other. This model can also be applied to the web of human sexual contacts, where the interactions between males and females can be thought of as two coupled growing networks.

• The model is analyzed using a rate equation approach, and the time evolution of the joint distribution of intra-links and cross-links is described. The total in-degree distribution in each network is shown to follow a power-law form.

• The distribution of the average number of nodes with intra-links and cross-links in each network is also derived, and these distributions also exhibit power-law behavior.

• In the weak coupling case, where the cross-linking is negligible, the power-law exponent of the intra-link distribution is equal to the exponent of the total link distribution, which coincides with the empirical findings.

• In the strong coupling case, the exponent of the cross-link distribution decreases as the coupling parameter increases, while the exponent of the intra-link distribution can take any value between the weak coupling limit and the total link distribution exponent.

• The model is shown to be flexible enough to represent a variety of complex systems, including the web of human sexual contacts, where the power-law exponents of the degree distributions of the sexes are derived.
</summary>

<summary>
• The paper introduces the concept of "shower partons" and their momentum distributions to represent the phenomenological fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.
• The shower parton distributions are determined by solving integral equations that relate them to the known fragmentation functions.
• The shower parton distributions are shown to be useful in problems where the knowledge of fragmentation functions alone is not sufficient, such as the interaction between a jet and its surrounding medium or the correlation between particles within a jet.
• The basic hadronization process is considered to be recombination, even for fragmentation in vacuum, and the shower parton distributions obtained are model-dependent.
• The paper suggests that the formal description of the Q^2 dependence of the shower parton distributions is a problem worth dedicated attention.
</summary>

<summary>
• The paper proposes a new iterative algorithm to solve a class of nonconvex semidefinite programming problems. The key idea is to locally approximate the nonconvex feasible set of the problem by an inner convex set, and the convergence of the algorithm to a stationary point is investigated under standard assumptions.
• The authors limit their applications to optimization problems with bilinear matrix inequality (BMI) constraints and provide a particular way to compute the inner positive semidefinite (PSD) convex approximation of a BMI constraint. Many applications in static output feedback controller design are shown, and two numerical examples are presented.
• The authors note that the proposed method can be extended to solve more general nonconvex semidefinite programming problems where an inner PSD-convex approximation of the feasible set can be managed, and this is also their future research direction.
</summary>

<summary>
• The paper discusses the use of discrete differential geometry to describe fermionic field theory, particularly the Dirac-Kahler formulation. It highlights the challenges in defining a discrete scheme that maintains the properties of the continuum, such as the Hodge star and the wedge product.

• The paper presents a proposal by Adams that introduces two parallel lattices to maintain the locality of the Hodge star and a finite element scheme to capture the properties of the wedge product. The authors build upon this proposal to describe chiral symmetry and exact flavor projection in the Dirac-Kahler formulation.

• The paper introduces additional complexes and operators to implement exact chiral and flavor projection simultaneously. It also discusses the implications of these projections on the path integral formulation, including the connection to the quarter-root trick used in lattice QCD.
</summary>

<summary>
• The paper investigates collaborative relay beamforming in cognitive radio networks under secrecy constraints. The authors formulate the problem as a semidefinite programming problem and provide an optimization framework to maximize the secrecy rates under both total and individual relay power constraints.
• The authors propose two suboptimal null space beamforming schemes to reduce the computational complexity. These schemes are shown to achieve near-optimal performance, especially in the high SNR regime, suggesting that null space beamforming is optimal at high SNRs.
• The authors observe that imposing individual relay power constraints leads to only small losses in the secrecy rates. They also find that the secrecy rate achieved by beamforming in the null space of both the eavesdropper's and primary user's channels is almost insensitive to different interference temperature limits.
• The authors provide numerical results to illustrate the performances of different beamforming schemes. They show that the suboptimal null space beamforming schemes are good alternatives to the optimal solution, as they are obtained with much less computational burden.
• The authors discuss the extension of their work to the case of multiple primary users and eavesdroppers, noting that the null space beamforming schemes can be extended to this scenario under the condition that the number of relay nodes is greater than the number of eavesdroppers or the total number of eavesdroppers and primary users.
</summary>

<summary>
• The @xmath0-invariance of the Maxwell equation was discovered a century ago, but in order to quantize the Maxwell field, a gauge fixing condition is necessary, which breaks the @xmath0 invariance. The purpose of the present paper is to demonstrate the benefits of keeping this fundamental symmetry when quantizing the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS).

• The authors use Dirac's six-cone formalism and realize all CFS as intersections of the null cone and a given surface in a six-dimensional Lorentzian space. They introduce auxiliary fields and use the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme to deal with the gauge freedom of the Maxwell field.

• The main result is a set of Wightman two-point functions for the Maxwell and auxiliary fields. The authors show that the classical and quantum structures of the free Maxwell field are locally the same in all conformally flat spaces, and they discuss the possibility of extending this approach to other free fields and @xmath0-invariant interactions.

• The authors define a second coordinate system, the polyspherical coordinate system, which makes the flatness feature of the CFS spaces apparent. They then transport the minkowskian @xmath0-invariant equations to get @xmath0-invariant equations in the CFS space.

• The authors apply the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme and solve the dynamical equations to obtain the modes, determine the quantum field, the subspace of physical states, and finally compute the two-point functions. They show that the subspace of physical states is the same in all CFS, which allows them to transport physical quantities from Minkowski space into the CFS space.

• The authors consider the particular case of de Sitter space and obtain simple expressions for the two-point functions related to the fields. They show that the two-point function for the Maxwell field has the same physical content as the Allen and Jacobson two-point function.

• The authors introduce two auxiliary fields, and as a consequence, the Maxwell field does not propagate "alone" but together with its two auxiliary fields. They discuss the possibility of using the two-point functions to propagate the electromagnetic field for some charge distribution given in other CFS, like FLRW spaces.

• The authors provide the expressions for the infinitesimal @x

<summary>
• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs where vertices with a certain number of chips can "fire" one chip to each of their neighbors. The game has a finite number of positions, and each initial position has a period and a transient length.
• The authors prove several lemmas about the parallel chip-firing game, including bounds on the number of chips on each vertex and the relationship between a position and its "complement" position.
• The authors characterize the possible periods for the parallel chip-firing game on complete bipartite graphs, showing that the only possible periods are 1, 2, or a divisor of the number of vertices in one of the sides.
• The authors then construct positions on complete k-partite graphs with period k for all k, demonstrating that all possible periods are achievable on these graphs.
• The authors discuss the relationship between period lengths and the structure of the underlying graph, conjecturing that period lengths are related to the lengths of subcycles in the graph.
• The authors suggest several directions for further research, including studying the transient length of games on certain graphs and the implications of "reducing" the parallel chip-firing game by removing chips.
• The parallel chip-firing game is a special case of the more general chip-firing game, which has connections to number theory, algebra, and combinatorics.
• The parallel chip-firing game can be used to simulate the deterministic fixed-energy sandpile, which is an important problem in statistical physics and a model of self-organized criticality.
• The parallel chip-firing game is an example of a cellular automaton, which have implications in fields ranging from biology to social science.
• The authors acknowledge the contributions of their mentor and other researchers who have provided guidance and advice on this problem.
</summary>

<summary>
• The source document discusses the observations and analysis of the short gamma-ray burst GRB 090510, which is interpreted as the merging of a binary neutron star system leading to the formation of a Kerr-Newman black hole.
• The analysis of the prompt emission and the precursor emission provides evidence for the formation of a dyadotorus, an axially symmetric configuration of the electron-positron plasma, which precedes the formation of the black hole.
• The delayed high-energy gamma-ray emission observed in GRB 090510 is linked to the accretion of matter onto the newly formed black hole, and its energetics are consistent with the formation of a Kerr black hole.
• The self-consistency of the analysis is verified by the agreement between the theoretically derived redshift and the spectroscopically measured value.
• The results of this study contrast with the usual assumption that the black hole precedes the gamma-ray burst emission, and instead suggest that the dyadotorus formation and the black hole formation are distinct events in the evolution of short gamma-ray bursts.
• The findings of this work have implications for the understanding of the high-energy emission observed in various systems harboring Kerr black holes, such as binary X-ray sources, microquasars, and active galactic nuclei.
</summary>

<summary>
* The paper discusses the renormalization of the Standard Model (SM) and two models with new physics beyond the SM, the SM with a real scalar triplet and the minimal left-right symmetric model, and demonstrates that the new physics does not decouple from the SM at one-loop.
* In the triplet model, the dependence of the W-boson mass on the top quark mass becomes logarithmic, and the scalar contributions to the W-boson mass are quadratic, allowing for a heavier Higgs boson than in the SM.
* The left-right symmetric model also exhibits a discontinuity between the SM and the new physics, as four input parameters are required in the new model, unlike the three in the SM, due to the non-decoupling nature of the new scalar fields.
</summary>

<summary>
• A choice of nonconstant meromorphic function on a compact Riemann surface realizes the surface as a finite sheeted branched covering of the Riemann sphere.
• Log-Riemann surfaces of finite type are certain branched coverings of the Riemann sphere by a punctured compact Riemann surface, given by certain transcendental functions of infinite degree.
• Log-Riemann surfaces of finite type are given by a pair of a compact Riemann surface and a meromorphic function on the punctured surface, with the differential having exponential singularities at the punctures.
• Exp-algebraic curves are a less rigid structure than log-Riemann surfaces, consisting of a punctured compact Riemann surface and equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions with exponential singularities at the punctures.
• To an exp-algebraic curve, one can associate a degree zero line bundle with a meromorphic connection, and this correspondence is one-to-one.
• The spaces of functions and differential forms with exponential singularities on an exp-algebraic curve are isomorphic to the spaces of meromorphic sections and forms on the associated line bundle.
• A Torelli-type theorem is proved, stating that the line bundle and the induced isomorphism between the spaces of meromorphic sections and forms determine the exp-algebraic curve.
• Functions and differentials with exponential singularities have appeared in the study of integrable systems and the Weierstrass problem.
• The paper also provides a detailed review of the basic definitions and results on log-Riemann surfaces and exp-algebraic curves.
</summary>

<summary>
* The paper discusses recent progress in understanding the physics of strongly correlated electronic systems using dynamical mean-field theory (DMFT) and its combination with realistic local-density approximation (LDA) calculations.
* The authors propose an interpolative approach for the self-energy in general multi-orbital situations, which can be encoded into a rational representation with coefficients determined by imposing various constraints.
* The slave-boson mean-field (SBMF) method and the Hubbard-I approximation are used to determine the functional dependence of these coefficients on doping, degeneracy, and the strength of the interaction.

* The authors compare the results of their interpolative method with more accurate but computationally demanding quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) calculations, and find a very satisfactory agreement in a wide range of parameters.
* The SBMF method is found to provide a better description of the low-frequency behavior and multiple occupancies compared to the Hubbard-I approximation, while the functional form of the atomic Green function from the Hubbard-I method is used to determine the positions of the atomic satellites.
* The authors discuss possible improvements to their algorithm, such as including lifetime effects, using more refined impurity solvers, and enforcing additional constraints to improve the accuracy of the mass renormalization and the number of electrons.

* The interpolative method is shown to be computationally efficient and numerically stable, making it a promising approach for exploring the parameter space of realistic solid-state systems where the bandwidth and the strength of the interaction are not known a priori.
* The authors stress that their method is not an attempt to develop an alternative method for solving the impurity problem, but rather a follow-up of the ideology of LDA theory, where approximations were designed by analytical fits to the QMC simulations.
* The paper demonstrates the potential of the interpolative approach for fast scans of the entire parameter space, which is crucial for simulating the properties of realistic solid-state systems.
* The authors conclude that their method provides a truly exceptional accuracy-to-efficiency ratio, and that further improvements can be achieved by utilizing better algorithms for determining the constraints.
</summary>

<summary>
* The study examines the effects of inert sites on the phase transitions of the Ziff-Gulari-Barshad (ZGB) model, which describes the oxidation of carbon monoxide over a catalytic surface. The researchers used mean-field (site and pair) approximations and Monte Carlo simulations to investigate the phase diagram, spinodal and transition lines, and the production rate of carbon dioxide as a function of the concentration of inert sites.
* The results show that the site approximation does not exhibit a continuous transition, while the pair approximation and Monte Carlo simulations reveal a critical concentration of inert sites above which the transition between the reactive and carbon monoxide-poisoned phases changes from first-order to continuous. The production rate of carbon dioxide is maximum at the first-order transition, but shifts towards the reactive window as the concentration of inert sites increases.
</summary>

<summary>
• The purpose of this paper is to discuss the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems in the crystal lattice, which is a generalization of the classical lattice.
• The crystal lattice is defined as an infinite graph that admits a free action of a free abelian group with a finite quotient graph.
• The authors construct a scaling limit of the crystal lattice by using a harmonic map and embed the scaled finite graph into a torus.
• The symmetric simple exclusion process and the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process are formulated on the crystal lattice, and their hydrodynamic limits are obtained.
• The key step in the proof is the local ergodic theorem, which is formulated using the notion of Γ-periodic local function bundles and two types of local averages.
• The proof of the local ergodic theorem is based on the one-block estimate and the two-blocks estimate.
• The derivation of the hydrodynamic equation follows the same manner as the case of the discrete torus.
• The authors mention related works on the hydrodynamic limit on spaces other than the Euclidean lattice and the problem of interacting particle systems evolving in random environments.
• The paper is organized into sections covering crystal lattices, the hydrodynamic limit, the replacement theorem, the proof of the main theorem, and appendices.
• The authors use Landau asymptotic notation throughout the paper.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study of harmonic maps was initiated by F.B. Fuller, J. Nash, and J.H. Sampson. The first general result on the existence of harmonic maps is due to Eells-Sampson. Harmonic maps are extrema (critical points) of the energy functional defined on the space of smooth maps between Riemannian (pseudo-Riemannian) manifolds.

• The tension field of a map is defined, and a map is said to be harmonic if its tension field vanishes identically. The Hessian of a harmonic map is defined, and the index of a harmonic map is the dimension of the tangent subspace on which the Hessian is negative definite.

• A harmonic map is said to be stable if its Morse index is zero, and unstable if its Morse index is non-zero. The map is said to be horizontally conformal if the restriction of the differential to the horizontal space is surjective and conformal.

• Harmonic maps have found applications in computational fluid dynamics, minimal surface theory, string theory, gravity, and quantum field theory. Most works on harmonic maps are between Riemannian manifolds, and the study of harmonic maps between pseudo-Riemannian manifolds requires some restrictions.

• An almost para-hermitian manifold is a smooth manifold endowed with an almost para-complex structure and a pseudo-Riemannian metric compatible with the structure. An almost paracontact manifold is a smooth manifold with a triplet structure satisfying certain conditions.

• A paraholomorphic map between almost para-hermitian and almost paracontact manifolds is defined, and it is shown that the tension field of any paraholomorphic map between a para-Sasakian manifold and an almost para-hermitian manifold lies in the contact subbundle.

• A parapluriharmonic map between an almost paracontact metric manifold and a pseudo-Riemannian manifold is defined, and it is shown that any paraholomorphic map between a para-Sasakian manifold and a para-Kähler manifold is parapluriharmonic and hence harmonic.

<summary>
* The star formation rate (SFR) of galaxies is an important measure for understanding the hierarchical build-up of the universe. Large-scale simulations have shown that unregulated star formation leads to an overabundance of high-mass galaxies, suggesting that some process must be able to stop or "quench" star formation before the galaxy grows too big.
* The answer seems to lie in supermassive black holes (SMBHs), which nearly all massive galaxies harbor in their centers. SMBHs grow through accretion of cold material, and the energy released can deposit energy into the interstellar medium of the host galaxy through jets or powerful outflows, a process known as "feedback."
* Indirect evidence of this feedback has been observed through scaling relationships between the mass of the SMBH and different properties of the host galaxy. However, much debate remains about the exact mechanism of AGN feedback and whether it plays a dominant role in the overall evolution of galaxies.
* The problem lies in determining accurate estimates of the SFR in AGN host galaxies, as well-calibrated indicators such as H-alpha emission and UV luminosity are significantly, if not completely, contaminated by the central AGN. Many studies therefore turn to the infrared (IR) regime, where dust re-emits the stellar light from young stars.
</summary>

<summary>
* Myles Hollander is a renowned statistician who has made significant contributions to the field of nonparametric statistics, particularly in the areas of rank tests, Bayesian nonparametrics, and reliability theory.
* Hollander's career has been shaped by his interactions with influential figures in statistics, such as Lincoln Moses, Ingram Olkin, and Frank Proschan, and his collaborations with his doctoral students, including Edsel Pea.
* Hollander has authored several books, including the successful "Nonparametric Statistical Methods" with Douglas Wolfe, and has served as the editor of the Theory and Methods section of the Journal of the American Statistical Association.
* Hollander's retirement from Florida State University is being celebrated with a conference honoring his contributions to the field of statistics and his department, and he looks forward to spending more time with his family and continuing his involvement in the statistical community.
</summary>

<summary>
• The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is an important topological invariant that can be computed for line arrangements. This invariant has various applications, such as distinguishing between connected components of the moduli space of smooth projective surfaces and searching for examples of Zariski pairs.
• Fan defined a graph associated with the multiple points of a line arrangement, and proved results concerning the projective fundamental group. The inverse implication of Fan's result has been conjectured and recently proved.
• The authors introduce the notion of a conjugation-free geometric presentation of the fundamental group and study the family of line arrangements whose fundamental groups have such presentations. They show that the fundamental group of a real arrangement whose graph is a union of disjoint cycles and has no line with more than two multiple points has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
• The authors also provide the exact group structure of the fundamental group for the simplest arrangement in this family, where the graph consists of a cycle of length 3 and all multiple points have multiplicity 3.
• The authors generalize their results to arrangements whose graphs are cycles of arbitrary length, and show that the fundamental group of such arrangements has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
• The authors also discuss the relation between their family of arrangements and other well-known families, such as nice and simple arrangements, and mention some initial computations regarding the completeness of conjugation-free geometric presentations.
</summary>

• The author introduces the A4 symmetry as a way to avoid mass degeneracy of neutrinos and charged leptons under the Z2 symmetry. After the introduction of the tri-bi maximal mixing pattern, people have tried to fit this mixing pattern through the A4 symmetry.

The author's approach to get non-zero Dirac CP violation is minimal, as they break the A4 symmetry explicitly by a single parameter in a single element of the Dirac neutrino mass matrix.

After the see-saw mechanism and diagonalization, this model gives rise to the tri-bi maximal mixing pattern.

<summary>
• Organic molecular crystals are emerging as excellent candidates for fabricating nanoscale devices, with potential applications in electronics and optoelectronics. The electronic structure of the interface between the organic and inorganic components plays a crucial role in determining the final device performance.

• Density functional theory (DFT) is commonly used to calculate the addition and removal energies of molecules, but the Kohn-Sham orbitals cannot be directly associated with quasiparticle energies. Local and semi-local approximations of the exchange-correlation functional perform poorly, even for the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) level.

• Constrained DFT (CDFT) is a more resource-efficient alternative to calculate the charge transfer energies of an organic molecule physisorbed on an inorganic substrate. CDFT avoids the calculation of a quasiparticle spectrum and instead replaces it with a series of total energy calculations for different charge distributions.

• The authors use CDFT to study the adsorption of a benzene molecule on a graphene sheet. They find that the addition and removal energies decrease in absolute value as the molecule is brought closer to the graphene sheet, which can be described by a classical electrostatic model.

• The presence of a stone-Wales defect in the graphene sheet does not significantly alter the charge transfer energies, as the density of states of graphene remains almost completely unchanged near its Fermi energy after introducing the defect.

• When multiple benzene molecules are present, the charge transfer energies change due to the interaction between the molecules. This can be explained by a simple classical effect, where the induced charge dipole in the neighboring molecules affects the electrostatic potential.

• The charge transfer energies calculated using CDFT agree well with the classical electrostatic model, which takes into account the finite dielectric constant of graphene, in contrast to the case of a perfect metal.

• The authors find that the charge transfer energies depend on the distance between the molecule and the graphene sheet, which is a consequence of the image charge formation. This effect cannot be described by standard Kohn-Sham DFT but is well captured by CDFT.

• The authors demonstrate that CDFT is a computationally inexpensive method that can be used to study the effects of structural defects

<summary>
* The study investigates the critical Casimir forces (CCFs) acting on two equally sized spherical colloids immersed in a near-critical binary liquid mixture and close to a homogeneous, planar substrate. The normal and lateral CCFs are characterized by universal scaling functions, which are studied using mean-field theory and a finite element method to calculate the order parameter profiles.
* The authors find that the presence of the substrate can lead to a change in the sign of the lateral CCF between colloids with opposite boundary conditions (BCs), and that the many-body contribution to the lateral CCF is always attractive, regardless of the BCs. They also compare their results to those for quantum-electrodynamic Casimir interactions and van der Waals forces between atoms near a solid surface, finding differences in the decay of the many-body contributions.
* The authors also consider the case where the two colloids are vertically aligned with respect to the substrate, and find that the many-body contribution to the normal CCF acting on the lower colloid is directed towards the substrate if the colloids have the same BCs, and away from the substrate if they have opposite BCs.
</summary>

<summary>
* Molecular hydrogen (H2) is the most abundant molecule in the universe and plays a crucial role in the chemistry of the interstellar medium. The formation of H2 is governed by the sticking of hydrogen atoms onto dust grain surfaces.
* Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are predicted to have characteristics similar to graphite surfaces and can act as efficient catalysts for H2 formation. Hydrogenation of PAH cations is an important route for H2 formation in the interstellar medium.
* The authors studied the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase using mass spectrometry. Their results show that odd hydrogenation states of coronene cations predominantly populate the mass spectrum.
* The authors derived the energy barriers for the second and fourth hydrogenations of coronene cations to be around 72 meV and 43 meV, respectively, while the third and fifth hydrogenations are barrierless.
* The authors' findings suggest that superhydrogenated PAH cations should also be found in the interstellar medium and act as catalysts for H2 formation, similar to their neutral counterparts.
* The authors' results highlight the presence of a barrier-no barrier alternation from one hydrogenated state to another, up to high hydrogenation states, which is different from previous theoretical predictions.
* The authors' experimental approach of studying the hydrogenation of PAHs in the gas phase demonstrates the feasibility of this method for investigating the formation of H2 in the interstellar medium.
* The authors' findings have implications for understanding the spatial distribution of H2 and PAHs in photodissociation regions (PDRs) and the contribution of PAH cations to the overall H2 formation rate in the interstellar medium.
</summary>

* The atom or atoms in an atomic clock are passive and do not "tick", so the clock needs an active oscillator. The resonance exhibited by the atoms varies with the details of the clock's construction and operation, and the oscillator drifts in relation to the knob setting.
* The SI second is defined by the resonance that "would be found" at absolute zero temperature, and a wave function is chosen to express the relation between a measured resonance and the imagined resonance at 0 K.
* The wave function incorporated into the operation of an atomic clock can never be unconditionally known, and the distinction within quantum theory between linear operators and probabilities implies a gap between any explanation and the evidence explained.

* The reading of a clock of an open machine has the form (n + φ), where n indicates the count of cycles and φ is the phase within the cycle. A channel from machine A to machine B is defined as a set of pairs, each pair of the form (tA, tB), where tA is an A-reading at which machine A can transmit a signal and tB is a B-reading at which the clock of machine B can register the reception of the signal.
* A logical symbol can propagate from one open machine to another only if the symbol arrives within the writing phase of the receiving machine, and this phase constraint on a channel is called logical synchronization.
* Three types of questions arise regarding the patterns of interrelated channels, the steering of open machines to approach given aiming points, and the response to deviations from aiming points.

* Assuming propagation is described by null geodesics in a Lorentzian 4-manifold with a metric tensor field, open machines can be represented as timelike worldlines, and two open machines are radar linkable if every point of the image of one is reached uniquely by one future-pointing null geodesic from the image of the other.
* A group of clock adjustments consists of functions on the real numbers having continuous, positive first derivatives, and to hypothesize a relation between a machine's clock and an accompanying proper clock, one has to assume a metric tensor field.
