• The invention provides two embodiments, one using an optically coupled circuit and the other using an electromechanical system, to achieve the automatic answering and hands-free communication features.
• The modular and portable design of the apparatus allows for easy installation and versatile use in various settings.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a repeaterless trunk and branch fiber optic ring network that utilizes remotely pumped optical amplifiers to reduce the number of undersea optical repeaters required. The network consists of a trunk fiber optic cable in a ring topology with one or more telecommunications hubs and branch assemblies connected to it.
• The hub assemblies are responsible for aggregating, grooming, and routing telecommunications traffic onto the trunk cable. One type of hub assembly includes a light emitting power source that transmits optical energy at a wavelength distinct from the signal wavelengths along the trunk cable to remotely power an optical amplifier located downstream.
• The branch assemblies consist of a cable station, a branch fiber optic cable, and a branching unit. The branch fiber optic cable transports bidirectional communications signals between the cable station and the trunk cable, and also unidirectionally transmits the optical energy from a light emitting power source to an optical amplifier embedded in the trunk cable or the branch cable.
• The combination of the trunk and branch structure, along with the remote powering of optical amplifiers, provides several advantages, including maintaining full connectivity in the event of a trunk cable cut, isolating branch cable cuts without compromising the ring integrity, and reducing the capital, operating, and maintenance costs of the communications network.
• The optical amplifiers used in the network are typically erbium doped fiber amplifiers, which can be effectively powered by a multiple order cascaded Raman laser operating in the 1450-1500 nm wavelength range, distinct from the 1500-1600 nm signal wavelengths.
• The present invention can be applied to both undersea and terrestrial communications systems, and is not limited to the specific number of components or the exact wavelengths described in the preferred embodiment.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention provides a cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices that can be quickly and easily installed or removed without visible fasteners. The cover plate device consists of two parts: an attachment member that is installed over the wiring device and mounted to it, and a cover plate member that is latched to the attachment member without the use of visible fasteners.
* The attachment member is symmetrical and has latching pawls at its ends, while the cover plate member has saw-tooth shaped racks on its inner surface that engage with the latching pawls. This allows the cover plate to accommodate variations in the flatness or evenness of the wall, making it suitable for use with multiple wiring devices installed in ganged boxes.
* The cover plate can be removed by inserting a tool through a slot in the bottom edge of the cover plate and using the tab on the attachment member as a fulcrum to pry the cover plate off. This design provides an improved cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices that is quickly and easily installed or removed and has no visible fasteners.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a collapsible light-shielding device for a screen, such as a television or monitor.
* The device consists of a number of annular strips that are concentrically nested and can slide over one another to be folded in or extended.
* The strips have a decreasing wall thickness in the axial direction, allowing the device to be positioned at various angles to the screen.
* The strips are equipped with hooks and locking elements to ensure reliable folding and unfolding.
* An adapter member is provided to allow the device to be attached to screens with flat or curved surfaces.
* The device can be made of solid, injection-molded strips or bent plate material with integrated hooks and locking elements.
* The invention provides a collapsible, inexpensive, and easily attachable light-shielding device for screens.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention discloses a solution that automatically informs a speaker to decrease their speaking rate when it exceeds a rate that a listener can understand. This can be accomplished by determining the speaker's speaking rate, comparing it against a speaking rate threshold based on the listener's proficiency, and notifying the speaker to slow down if the rate is too high.
* The invention can be implemented in various ways, such as through a wearable device that monitors the speaker's rate and provides sensory feedback, or through a networked system that utilizes remote processing capabilities to perform the necessary speech analysis and comparisons.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a device for the optical recording of rapid processes with a TV camera. The device comprises means for deviating and suppressing the beam to make the scanning beam run successively and cyclically over N lines of a picture plane.

• The device includes a cyclic line counter that carries out one counting step for each line pulse and supplies an end-of-count pulse after p line pulses, where N/p is an integer significantly greater than 1. This end-of-count pulse is applied to the beam suppression circuit of the TV camera.

• The device also includes a sawtooth generator synchronized with the output pulses of the counter to control the vertical deviation of the beam. The sawtooth generator and the beam suppression circuit are controlled via a delay device, the delay time of which constitutes a selectable part of a line period.

• The line counter can be a programmable counter, allowing the value of p to be adjusted to optimize the time resolution and spatial resolution for the process being recorded.

• The device can also be configured to move the scheme of the scanned lines from one scanning cycle to the next, filling in the gaps between the lines of a picture with succeeding scans.

• The device is suitable for recording IR, UV, or X-ray pictures, in addition to visible light processes, and the recorded data can be digitized and stored for computer-assisted analysis.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention provides a solution for integrating voice calls with multimedia sessions as a blended call. A blended call is a call that blends voice and multimedia functions into a single communication session.
• The invention uses a multimedia server associated with a telephony server, where the multimedia server has software (a "blender") that manages blended calls, using the functions of the multimedia server where appropriate and the telephony server where appropriate.
• The blender software receives an incoming call, initiates a single session with two call components (a voice call component and a multimedia call component), and handles the voice call component through the telephony server and the multimedia call component through the multimedia server.
• The blender may include an indication (a "loopback signal" or "loopback indication") to prevent the telephony server from redirecting or looping the voice call component back to the blender, avoiding infinite loops.

• For an outgoing call from a user with blended capabilities, the telephony server refers the call to the blender function on the multimedia server, which then initiates the two call components.
• The invention is well-suited for use with a Session Initiation Protocol for Telephones (SIP-T) configuration, as the information in the SIP-T messages is helpful in setting up and tearing down the parallel call components.
• Alternatively, an Intelligent Network (IN) signal may be used to determine if a blended call is being handled, and if so, refer the call to the blender.
• The invention allows existing customer premises equipment and network elements to be used to support multimedia capabilities, prolonging the viability of existing network devices.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a content synchronization framework that allows connected devices to perform contextual synchronization over various communication networks.
* The framework has a central reference point server that processes synchronization requests from connected client devices and returns responses including bundles of files.
* The client device sends its context and dynamic attributes to the central reference point server, which uses this information to construct the response bundles.
* The response bundles include file descriptions with properties such as download priority, location, and actions to be performed on the files.
* The client device creates a delta list of files to download based on the response and downloads the files in the prioritized order.
* The framework employs data compression and concurrent priority-based downloading to optimize bandwidth usage and communication.
* The framework supports resumption of synchronization from the specific bundle that experienced a failure during the last connection disruption.
* The central reference point server can cache responses to improve scalability and efficiency of the framework.
* The framework is highly scalable and deployable worldwide with support for multiple languages and character sets.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention provides a system and method that allows a finder of a lost or misplaced object to anonymously communicate with the owner of the object. The system involves the owner registering a unique ID and their contact information on a centralized database, and then associating that ID with a virtual locale, such as a website.
* When a finder finds an object with the registered ID, they can access the virtual locale and communicate with the owner using only the ID, without revealing their own identity or contact information. The system generates anonymous email addresses for the communication between the finder and the owner.
* The system also allows the owner to manage their registered IDs and associated objects, view open cases where finders have communicated with them, and edit their contact information. Finders can also view open cases, send one-way messages to owners, and open new cases to communicate with owners.

* The system utilizes a centralized database to store the associations between IDs, owner contact information, and open cases. The system also includes features to validate user credentials and prevent unauthorized access.
* The system can be implemented using various programming languages, operating systems, and database systems, and can integrate with existing instant messaging and text messaging platforms to facilitate communication between finders and owners.
* The system provides a timely and anonymous communication channel between finders and owners, which helps facilitate the return of lost or misplaced objects to their rightful owners while protecting the privacy of both parties.
* The system can be used to protect a variety of portable possessions, such as keys, electronics, and personal items, by allowing owners to easily register and manage their tagged objects.
* The system offers a user-friendly interface and various options for owners and finders to interact with the system, including the ability to return to the main menu at any time without entering any information.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to electron multipliers used in photomultipliers and particle detectors. It describes two types of conventional electron multipliers: discrete dynode multipliers and continuous electron multipliers.

* The foil electron multiplier, the invention described in this document, uses a sequential series of thin foils in an evacuated enclosure to multiply electrons in a series of transmission stages. This design is believed to create a larger avalanche of electrons and allow for position-sensitive information.

* Advantages of the foil electron multiplier include higher gain per stage, simpler and lower-cost fabrication, ability to cover larger areas, and intrinsic rejection of ion feedback. The gain of the foil electron multiplier is maximized by optimizing the electron transmission, grid transmission, and secondary electron emission yield.

* The foil electron multiplier does not experience ion feedback, as ions generated at one stage cannot be re-transmitted back. The gain of the foil electron multiplier is represented by a mathematical equation that describes the avalanche of electrons through the stages.

* The preferred foil dimensions are 0.5 cm to 2x4 cm, with an areal thickness of 0.2 to 1 μg/cm2. Carbon is the preferred foil material, as it provides the thinnest and most uniform foils. A support grid is required for the thin foils.

* The foil electron multiplier was demonstrated using 0.6 μg/cm2 carbon foils, with a 200 line-per-inch nickel grid for structural support. The multiplier was constructed with a series of foil stages followed by a conductive anode, with resistors between the stages.

* Experiments were conducted with a 50 keV O+ ion beam, measuring the output current as a function of the applied voltage for 2, 3, and 4 foil stage configurations. The results showed a higher gain per stage compared to microchannel plate detectors.

* The foil electron multiplier exhibits a gain behavior described by the mathematical equations presented, and demonstrates a higher gain efficiency than conventional electron multipliers.

* The invention is intended to be used in photomultiplier tubes and particle detectors, such as channel electron multipliers and microchannel plates, which are used extensively in electron spectrometers, mass

<summary>
* The 3-D Phenomenoscope is a system that allows ordinary 2D motion pictures to be viewed with a 3D effect. It takes advantage of the Pulfrich effect, where lateral motion in a movie appears to have depth.
* The system uses viewing glasses with individually controllable lenses. A digital sensor and processor in the glasses capture and analyze the movie frames to detect lateral motion and control the lens states accordingly.

* The glasses have three lens states: clear-clear, clear-dark, and dark-clear. The lens states are synchronized with the lateral motion in the movie to create the 3D effect.
* The system works with any motion picture format, whether film or digital, and can be used for viewing in theaters, on TVs, or on computer screens.

* The system overcomes the problems of previous 3D movie technologies, which required special cameras, projection equipment, and caused viewer discomfort.
* The key technologies used in the 3-D Phenomenoscope include materials that can change transparency, digital photo sensors, and miniature special-purpose computers.

* The preferred embodiment uses an intensity edge-based algorithm to detect lateral motion in the movie frames and control the lens states accordingly.
* Other embodiments may use more complex algorithms to detect different types of motion and control the lenses for optimal 3D effect.
* The 3-D Phenomenoscope provides a way to view ordinary 2D movies in 3D without any modifications to the original content or viewing equipment.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to an apparatus and method for dicing semiconductor wafers using pressure to mechanically separate the individual die from the wafer without the use of a wafer saw. The method involves forming trenches along the scribe lines on a semiconductor wafer and then applying a mechanical pressure to the semiconductor wafer, causing a "clean break" of the wafer along the scribe lines and singulating the individual die.

• The apparatus comprises a pad for supporting a semiconductor wafer, a positioning member to position the semiconductor wafer on the pad, and a pressure mechanism to apply a mechanical pressure to the wafer so as to singulate the individual die on the wafer. The pressure can be applied in the X and Y directions or in a circular motion to cause the wafer to break along the horizontal and vertical scribe lines.

• The invention can be used with any sized wafer or any type of die, and the trenches can be formed by etching or partially cutting the wafer using a wafer saw. The trenches can also be formed on the bottom or non-active surface of the wafer. The invention aims to address the problems associated with the use of a wafer saw for dicing semiconductor wafers, such as the slow process, maintenance issues, and potential chipping of thin wafers.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a field emission display (FED) device with a protection structure that prevents damage to the field emission elements. The protection structure includes one or more reduction plates or electrodes that are negatively charged to attract and deflect positive ions away from the cathode.

* The reduction plates can be arranged in an elongated, parallel configuration adjacent to the rows of field emission elements, or in a meshwork or net-shaped pattern among the field emission elements. This prevents the positive ions from inducing current surges that can damage the field emission elements.

* The FED device with the protection structure can be fabricated using conventional deposition and etching techniques to form the cathode, reduction plates, and field emission elements on the same plane.

* The negative bias voltage applied to the reduction plates attracts the positive nitrogen and oxygen ions, preventing them from reaching the cathode and causing current-induced damage to the field emission elements.

* The protection structure substantially prolongs the lifetime of the field emission elements in the FED device by deflecting the discharge path of the ionized gases away from the cathode and field emission elements.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to an image sensor that includes multiple imaging planes. Typical CCD image sensors are formed on flat, circular semiconductor substrates and can only image in a single plane.
* The image sensor of the present invention includes a semiconductor substrate with opposed major surfaces and edges. One of the edges has a surface that is receptive to light, and an image sensor element is formed adjacent to this edge.
* The image sensor element includes a charge collection and transfer means, and a means in the substrate guides charge carriers in the image sensing region toward the charge collection and transfer means.
* The image sensor includes an imaging plane on the top surface and imaging planes on two edge surfaces bordering the top surface. Doped layers create a waveguide-like structure adjacent the edges of the sensor to enable edge detection.
* The image sensor can be used to simultaneously image multiple planes, such as two opposing surfaces or the surface of a passageway. It can also be used for color applications by placing different color filters over the imaging planes.
* The thickness of the lightly doped layer in the substrate is important as it determines the effective vertical aperture dimension in the edge surfaces of the sensor.
* The image sensor can be fabricated using processing techniques compatible with other image sensors, allowing it to be easily incorporated into various types of known image sensors.
</summary>

<summary>
• This application claims the benefit of a provisional application filed on March 22, 2005. The present invention relates to home networks that employ devices with power management systems. Power management is desirable for home networks because network appliances can consume significant amounts of power even when not performing their primary functions.

• Currently, a network master node must perform network administrative functions even when it is not performing its own primary functions. This makes it difficult for the master node to enter a power-saving mode, leading to higher overall power consumption. It has been proposed to allow network slave nodes to promote themselves to become the new master node, but this may not result in the best-qualified node being selected.

• The invention provides methods for transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device. When the master device is instructed to enter a power management state, it sends data to a slave device to enable that device to perform the administrative functions. The master device then enters the power management state, and the slave device becomes the new master node.

• The master device sends a transfer request to the slave devices, and if only one responds, that device is selected to receive the administrative functions. If multiple devices respond, the master device selects the most qualified device based on factors such as network visibility or device capabilities. The selected slave device then receives the administrative functions and becomes the new master node.

• The network slave device waits for a transfer request from the master device. If the slave device is not in a power-saving mode, it accepts the request by sending a reply message. If the slave device is then selected by the master device, it receives the administrative functions and becomes the new master node.

• When any device on the network becomes activated, it first checks for the presence of a network master node. If no master node is found, the activated device automatically becomes the master node and performs the administrative functions.

• The invention allows the total power consumption of the home network to be minimized by enabling the master node to enter a power-saving mode, while ensuring that the network administrative functions are still performed by the most qualified available device.

• The network master node can transfer the administrative functions to a slave node while the slave node is performing its own primary functions, intermittently with the slave node's primary functions, or after the slave node has completed its primary functions.

• The invention provides a flexible and efficient way to manage power consumption in a home network while maintaining optimal

<summary>
• The invention relates to arrangements of antenna elements to measure the direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation. The prior art of UK 1449196 describes the use of a triplet to define fixed angles in the elevation plane, within which angle measurements were made by other means.
• This invention extends these ideas to optimize angle measurements, using the triplet itself, notably over selected sectors at low elevation angles. The array may either operate in a receive mode, in which case unambiguous angle measurement is provided by the signal processing circuits embodied in the antennae receivers, or in a transmit mode in which case the transmitted signal from each antenna in the array must be coded so that it can be identified to enable a quotient representing angle to be derived for each triplet in a remote receiver.
• The antenna array comprises at least four antennae spaced so as to provide at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane, each triplet characterized by the spacing of its elements and the height of the centre element above the ground plane. The array may be used to monitor the height of aircraft approaching to land, which has not been easily achieved with the standard secondary surveillance radar system.
• The design aims to provide unambiguous angle measurements up to about 7 degrees and measurement accuracy and resolution of the order +/-0.05 degrees from 3 degrees, at which aircraft normally approach to land, down to the lowest angle possible (about +0.5 degrees in this case). The values for the spacing (d) and height (h) of the triplets are optimized for approximately the same elevation angles, so that the amplitude S is at a maximum and altering slowly at angles where sensitive measurements are needed.
• The three triplets are arranged to give their best measurements at different elevation angles, and all readings are examined at each elevation angle to decide which triplet measurement is to be preferred, and the extent of the agreement between the three readings is a measure of the integrity of the system. A suitably weighted average of the three readings will give the optimum result.
• The highest element is at 22.75 wavelengths, which is about 7 meters from the ground. It is noted that, subject to a small variation to allow antenna elements to be shared between triplets, h=2d, and that common values of sin θ satisfy both equations (4) and (

<summary>
• The present invention relates to high-intensity, thermal, efficient incandescent lamps, subminiature lamps, lamp assemblies, and a lamp system with a liquid-tight seal. Conventional subminiature lamps have issues with adhesive breakdown, thermal expansion mismatch, and moisture ingress, leading to early failures.
• The invention uses a high-temperature polymer, such as a fluoroelastomer, to directly surround and compress the glass envelope of the subminiature lamp. This provides extended axial sealing, heat resistance, ease of handling, and increased resistance to invasion and chemical attack.
• The polymer seal support forms a housing around the glass envelope and the conductive base, creating a liquid-tight seal. The seal length is much longer than conventional O-ring seals, and the absence of adhesive allows for better centering of the lamp. Potting material can also be used to further protect the internal components.

• The polymeric seal support can be designed with different materials or densities in the upper and lower portions to optimize support and insulation. The axial bottom face of the seal support can also seal against the socket, providing additional friction and sealing.
• The longer seal length and single-surface sealing of the polymeric support offer advantages over conventional O-ring seals, which require two sealing surfaces and can have issues with uneven compression and poor sealing.
• The minimization of internal air volume and sealing points, along with the use of high-temperature, chemically resistant materials, helps prevent the ingress of harmful fluids and vapors that can degrade the lamp components and lead to early failures.

• The assembly process involves inserting the conductive base into the polymeric seal support, securing the leads, and injecting potting material to fill the internal space. This technique can be applied to any situation requiring high-heat, chemical, and insulation properties, not just medical subminiature lamps.
• The invention provides a solution to the problems of conventional subminiature lamps, including adhesive breakdown, thermal expansion mismatch, and moisture ingress, leading to extended bulb life and increased user safety.
• The focus of the invention is on medical subminiature lamps, but the techniques can be applied to any situation requiring high-heat, chemical, and insulation properties.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a technique for realizing a Generalized Decision Feedback Equalizer (GDFE) Precoder for multi-user (MU) MIMO systems. This technique significantly reduces the computational cost while resulting in no capacity loss.
• The described implementation of a GDFE Precoder relaxes the requirement for knowledge of the covariance matrix (Szz) corresponding to "Least Favorable Noise." This is the key component in conventional design of a GDFE Precoder and requires extensive computational cost.
• The described implementation of a GDFE Precoder achieves significant improvement in computational cost over conventional GDFE Precoders. It provides a uniform framework for realizing a GDFE Precoder.
• The method computes a filter matrix C using one of several alternative formulas, and based on the computation of the filter matrix C, computes the transmit filter matrix B, the feedforward filter matrix F, and the interference pre-cancellation matrix G.
• The described implementation of a GDFE Precoder does not require channel reduction when the Input Covariance Matrix (Sxx) for downlink channel is rank deficient. It is suitable for improving the performance of various MU-MIMO wireless systems.
• The methods provided in the invention are well-suited to high speed digital cellular telephony, including developing standards such as IMT-Advanced, and other forms of high speed digital communication, including wired communications.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, particularly an axial fan with an increased intake airflow rate without modifying the assembling conditions with other elements. This is to enhance the heat-dissipating performance of the fan.
• The housing of the heat-dissipating device includes an outer frame with a passage for guiding air streams. The sidewall of the passage at the air inlet side extends radially outwards to enlarge the intake area of the air streams.
• The outward extension of the sidewall can also be configured at the air outlet side, creating a symmetrical structure. The sidewall can extend radially outwards in a circular, elliptic, or frustum-conical manner.

• When the lateral side of the housing cannot be extended due to dimensional limitations, a part of the sidewall may be cut off to form a notch, enlarging the intake airflow area at the lateral side.
• The heat-dissipating device can be used within a system casing with electrical elements, or combined with a heat sink to be mounted on a central processing unit (CPU).
• The inclined portion of the sidewall can guide the air streams toward the central portion of the heat sink, where the highest temperature is, enhancing the heat-dissipating effects.
• The outward extension of the sidewall can enlarge the air inlet or outlet area, and the dimensions of the blades can be increased accordingly, greatly improving the airflow rate and heat-dissipating efficiency.
</summary>

<summary>
* The electroluminescent display panel described in the text is composed of various layers laminated on a glass substrate. The first and second luminescent layers are made of different materials, with the first layer emitting light without visible red components and the second layer emitting light with visible red components.

* The display panel has a single layer portion and a double layer portion, with the double layer portion emitting a lemon-colored light that is a mixture of green and orange. The threshold voltages for the single and double layer portions are different, allowing the display to show different colors by changing the driving voltage.

* The display panel is suitable for use as an instrument panel in an automobile, with the green light display used at night and the lemon light display used during the day. The lemon light has a higher luminance to cope with sunlight.

* Alternatively, a color filter can be used instead of the second luminescent layer, with the color filter emitting red light at high voltages and the first luminescent layer emitting green light at low voltages, resulting in a yellow display.

* The electroluminescent display panel can be made in a simple structure and at a low cost, as it can display different colors by simply changing the driving voltage without the need for an intermediate electrode.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a portable communications terminal for Internet/network telephony that establishes a wireless connection to a connecting unit, such as a computer or mobile phone, to access the Internet or a network. The terminal has audio means, converting means, and protocol means to handle communication according to a standardized Internet/network protocol like TCP/IP, allowing it to independently control and communicate data packets.
• The system includes the terminal, a connecting unit, and a service server connected to the Internet/network that can handle and control the connection between users, as well as provide additional functionalities like news, mails, and chat. The method involves establishing a wireless connection, transmitting user information to the server, and handling the received and transmitted data using the terminal's protocol means and the wireless connection.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention describes a method for fabricating a structure useful in semiconductor circuitry, which involves growing a buffer layer of non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide directly or indirectly on a semiconductor substrate, and then depositing a Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide on the buffer layer. This allows the integration of Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric materials on semiconductors without the formation of a low-dielectric constant layer at the interface.
• The invention also describes the use of a Ge buffer layer on the semiconductor substrate, which can prevent or minimize the formation of the low-dielectric constant layer and allow for the epitaxial growth of the high-dielectric constant oxides. The Ge buffer layer can also be used to integrate high-dielectric constant oxides on GaAs substrates, which are otherwise unstable in the required growth temperatures.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a receiver input circuit with multiple amplification control loops to eliminate distortions caused by non-linear components. The first control loop prevents overloading of the mixer stage and varactor diodes, while the second control loop prevents overloading of the mixer stage and frequency influences on the oscillator.

* The third control loop, with a lower response threshold and bandwidth, can be used to support the other control loops. The response threshold of the third control loop can also be controlled by the second control loop to provide better protection against stronger spurious signals.

* The input circuit includes an input network with reactance elements and a PIN diode for controllable signal attenuation, a preamplifier stage, a mixer and oscillator stage, and an intermediate frequency filter.

* The amplification control is achieved by distributing the operating current between the PIN diode and a shunt resistor, which has the advantage of maintaining a constant operating power during control and avoiding temperature changes in an integrated circuit.

* The input network can be further developed with additional PIN diodes and reactance elements to increase the control range and selectivity of the input circuit.

* The input network can also include a tunable selective circuit to achieve higher selectivity while avoiding strong attenuation during control.

* The tunable network can be aligned using an iteration-free method, and a single twin varactor diode can be used to form the resonant circuits, eliminating the need for separate adjustment of the tuning voltage.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a system for spontaneously setting up a collaborative work-sharing environment between physically distant individuals during a telephone call. It allows users to share information, conduct video conferences, and engage in other collaborative activities while maintaining their initial voice connection.

* The system uses a collaboration button and indicator on the telephone set to indicate the availability of network collaboration between the parties. When the indicator is illuminated, the system can establish a work-share environment upon one party activating the collaboration button.

* The collaboration control program on the user's desktop PC communicates with the telephone to control the collaboration indicator and sense the collaboration button. It can launch collaboration application programs or bring them to the foreground, and communicate with the collaboration control programs of remote PCs to determine if they can interoperate.

* The system can be implemented using a call control unit with phone proxies or in a peer-to-peer architecture. It can also be integrated with the computer, using the computer's input devices and voice capabilities instead of a separate telephone.

* The invention can be implemented as a computer program and can be carried on various forms of carrier media, such as storage media or signals transmitted over a network.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a method for inserting advertising clips into a video sequence. The method aims to optimize the visual impact of the inserted advertising clip by ensuring continuity between the regions of interest in the video sequence and the advertising clip.
* The method involves generating salience maps for the video sequence and the advertising clips, determining a degree of similarity between the salience maps, and selecting the advertising clip with the highest degree of similarity to be inserted at the insertion point.
* The insertion point is preferably a shot change in the video sequence, as this ensures a smooth transition for the viewer. The salience maps can be generated from the last n pictures of the video sequence and the first p pictures of the advertising clip.
* The device for implementing the method includes a processing unit, memory, and input/output interface to receive the video sequence and advertising clips, process them, and output the enhanced video sequence with the inserted advertising clip.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention relates to the use of a recessed mask structure to prevent localized high electrical fields at intersections with resulting lower electrical breakdown in very small dimension semiconductor devices. The recessed mask structure is achieved through a unique process that permits both the benefit of having a recessed surface of the mask with respect to a device surface where there may be high electric field concentration points, and the benefit of having a final mask thickness that is selectable and no thicker than necessary.
• The high field at the pointed regions is now away from the cap-mask interface, and the material of the mask which usually has a higher dielectric constant and can affect the overall dielectric properties of the device can be minimized with the dimension being selected independently of consideration for the planarization process. The recessed mask structure of the invention also provides a lower and predictable overall capacitance, which is valuable for faster signal propagation in the interconnect wiring.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a digital signal processing technique for designing radio receivers. It utilizes predictive coding principles to implement a simple down-converting analog-to-digital converter.

* By placing the sampler inside the predictive loop, the predictive loop filter can be implemented using digital signal processing techniques, eliminating the complexities introduced by the use of discrete-time analog circuitry.

* The dynamic range performance of the digital predictive encoder is further extended by utilizing the digital output of the loop to generate the signal for controlling a variable gain amplifier placed at the front of the predictive loop input.

* The DC offset performance of the converter is greatly enhanced through the incorporation of an offset nulling digital signal processing element, which provides an estimate of the offsets introduced by the various circuits.

* The use of interpolative type encoders (i.e., sigma-delta converters) in the analog-to-digital conversion of a high-frequency intermediate frequency (IF) signal has been advocated by many authors, but there remain numerous implementation challenges.

* The Downconverting Digitizer of the present invention achieves conversion of the modulated IF signal to the digital representation, downconversion of the modulated IF signal to a digital representation of the baseband in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components, and automatic control of the processed modulated IF signal amplitude to extend the dynamic range of the digitization process.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to the use of nanoimprint lithography to fabricate arrays of semiconductor nanotraces between electrodes, which can be used as sensors or for multiplex detection of analytes. The nanotraces have a high surface-to-volume ratio, making them highly sensitive to changes in their local environment, such as the binding of target molecules to anchored probe molecules on the nanotraces.
* The fabrication process involves using a nanoimprint template to pattern the semiconductor nanotraces, followed by etching to transfer the pattern into the semiconductor layer. Anchor probe molecules, such as nucleic acid sequences, can then be synthesized directly on the surface of the nanotraces using photogenerated reagents, with each sensor device in the array having a unique anchor probe sequence.
* The binding of target molecules to the anchored probe molecules on the nanotraces results in a change in the electrical conductivity of the nanotraces, which can be detected and used to identify the presence and concentration of the target molecules. The multiplex detection array can be used for a variety of applications, including diagnostic testing and environmental monitoring.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention provides a method of singulating and plating semiconductor packages, where the side surfaces of the leads are plated to prevent contamination.
• The method involves partially or fully cutting the leadframe and then plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads.
• The side surfaces of the singulated packages can have different shapes and heights depending on the cutting blades used.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a dual mode mobile terminal that can selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN).
* The WLAN access point gathers service information about the neighboring WWAN base stations and provides this information to the mobile terminal.
* The mobile terminal can use the service information to quickly connect to the WWAN when the WLAN signal becomes weak, avoiding connection drops.
* The first wireless module of the mobile terminal is turned off when connected to the WLAN, and turned on when the WLAN signal becomes weak to connect to the WWAN.
* The mobile terminal can select the serving WWAN base station with the strongest signal strength using the service information provided by the WLAN access point.
* The invention provides a method for the mobile terminal to switch from the WLAN to the WWAN in a timely manner to avoid dropped or delayed connections.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a new process for the manufacture of multilayered electrical components, such as capacitors, coils, and resistors. The process involves the formation of laminate sub-assemblies on decals, which are then stacked and fused together to form the final assembly.
* The process eliminates several steps from the conventional manufacturing process, such as cutting and end-termination, resulting in significant cost savings and improved reliability. The process also allows for the fabrication of smaller and more complex component configurations.
* The key steps in the process include: (1) providing electrodes on a decal, (2) depositing electrical components (e.g., dielectric material) on the electrodes, (3) stacking the sub-assemblies in a precise, registered manner, and (4) fusing the components together during a heating step.

* The process can be used to produce a variety of multilayered electrical components, including capacitors, coils, resistors, and combinations thereof. The elimination of cutting and lamination steps helps to prevent defects such as delamination and microcracks.
* The process allows for the fabrication of smaller and more complex component configurations, including non-rectangular shapes and lower voltage ratings. It also enables in-process inspection and enhanced reliability compared to conventional manufacturing methods.
* The use of decals in the process allows for rapid response to customer demands, as inventory can be partially carried in decal form and assembled as needed.

* The process can be adapted to manufacture a range of electronic ceramic devices, including multilayer ferrite inductors, multilayer substrates with buried metal circuitry, semiconductor packages, and precision resistor networks.
* The coil manufacturing process involves the formation of spiral coil patterns on decals, which are then laminated with non-conducting material and stacked to form the final coil structure. This eliminates the need for laborious coil winding.
* The versatility of the process allows for the integration of various components, such as resistors, coils, and capacitors, within a single multilayered assembly, enabling the fabrication of more complex electronic devices.
* The overall advantages of the new manufacturing process include smaller part sizes, lower voltage ratings, no shape limitations, enhanced in-process inspection, elimination of cutting-related defects, and reduced labor and capital investment requirements.
</summary>

<summary>
• This application claims benefit from a U.S. Provisional Application filed on March 20, 2008. The invention was made with United States Government support under a grant from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency/Office of Naval Research.
• The present invention relates to cellular materials used in structural applications, specifically materials comprising hierarchical cellular lattices and related methods of using and manufacturing the same. Sandwich panels are structural materials that may comprise a core enclosed between two sheets of material.
• The invention discloses a sandwich panel core or the like that may be comprised of a lattice structure utilizing a network of hierarchical trusses, synergistically arranged, to provide support and other functionalities. The resulting structure maintains a low weight while providing high specific stiffness and strength.

• The invention discloses a first lattice structure comprising a first primary array with an array of first order cells, and an ancillary array with an array of second order cells, where the ancillary array is nested with the first primary array.
• The invention further discloses a second lattice structure comprising a second primary array with an array of first order cells, where the second primary array is mated with the first primary array to form a third lattice structure.
• The invention discloses methods of making the structures, including forming the first lattice structure by providing the first primary array and the ancillary array, and nesting the ancillary array with the first primary array.

• The materials for manufacturing the unit cells encompass any material subject to deformation, punch and die, casting, injection molding, or other forming methods, including metals, metal alloys, inorganic polymers, organic polymers, ceramics, glasses, and all composite derivatives, or any combination thereof.
• The invention discloses various applications for the lattice structures, including use as the cores of sandwich panel structures, impact or blast load mitigation, heat exchange, catalysts, and thin film batteries.
• The invention discloses various methods of manufacturing the unit cells and arrays, including injection molding, investment casting, and other techniques, and the use of the arrays as templates for further processing.
</summary>

<summary>
• The process described in the text involves the co-production of power and hydrocarbons through the integration of a coal-to-liquid (CTL) facility and an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) facility. The CTL facility includes a dry gasification stage, Fischer-Tropsch hydrocarbon synthesis stages, and various supporting processes, while the IGCC facility includes a wet gasification stage, a sour shift stage, and a gas combustion and expansion stage.

• The integration of the two facilities allows for the optimization of energy efficiency, capital and operating costs, and CO2 capture and sequestration. The IGCC facility can be sized to maximize the economy of scale for power export, and the shared air separation unit between the two facilities can benefit from improved energy efficiency and lower costs.

• The fuel gas produced by the CTL facility is used as fuel in the IGCC facility, allowing for the production of steam at higher pressure and/or temperature. The integration also enables the capture of CO2 from the IGCC facility's off-gas, which can be combined with the CO2 produced by the CTL facility for export or further use.

• The combination of dry and wet gasification technologies in the integrated process provides advantages in terms of the characteristics of the intermediate streams, with the wet gasification stage producing a combustion gas with a higher hydrogen content and the dry gasification stage producing a synthesis gas precursor with a lower hydrogen content, which can be enriched using the hydrogen-rich gas from the wet gasification stage.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention provides a method for preparing a solid device for use as an oxide superconducting material. This is accomplished by uniformly coating a blocking film or passivation film over the spaces or micro-holes in the surface portion of the superconducting material to prevent the removal of oxygen from that portion.
* The invention also involves adding oxygen to the surface or portion close to the surface of the superconducting material, and then heat treating the entire body to position the added oxygen in the appropriate atom location. This ensures that the surface portion has the same conductivity characteristics as the internal portion.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to an apparatus for the preparation of foam sheet samples for microscopic examination, which allows for the creation of precisely measured laboratory foam sheet cross-sectional specimens.
• The apparatus includes a base structure, a clamping arrangement to grasp the foam sheet specimen without damaging it, and a screw thread specimen advance mechanism to prepare repetitive samples with uniform thickness and parallel cut edges.
• The method provided by the present invention preserves the structure of the individual cells within the sample, allowing for detailed microscopic examination without distortion or mutilation.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention relates to a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination with respect to the vertical assumed by a seismometer, especially those designed to operate on the ocean floor, and for leveling the seismic motion detectors carried by such a unit.
* The seismic motion detectors are suspended at the end of a shaft protruding from a ball rotating in an annular seat to form a free-moving pendulum.
* A spring-loaded plunger, positioned above the ball, is restrained from contact with its surface by a pin connected to a linearly acting solenoid.
* After the seismometer has been positioned for operation, the solenoid is activated, causing the pin to be pulled from the plunger, which then extends to contact the surface of the ball, locking it, the shaft, and detector(s) in their positions.
* The angle of inclination that the seismometer assumed with respect to the vertical at the time the ball was clamped can be determined by measuring the acute angle formed by the ball, shaft, and detector(s) in their locked position.
* The invention also provides a simple and inexpensive apparatus for self-leveling the seismic motion detectors used in a seismometer designed to operate on the ocean floor.
* The detector(s), support means, solenoid, and plunger are preferably mounted to the door of a water-tight instrument housing, which is rigidly mounted to the seismometer frame.
* The water-tight instrument housing, mounted on the lowest portion of the frame, will also tend to embed itself if the ocean floor is mud, providing a good path for seismic waves traveling through the ocean floor to the chassis of the water-tight compartment.
* The invention both levels the seismic motion detectors carried in a seismometer and preserves the angle of inclination with respect to the vertical that the seismometer assumes during its operation.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention provides a humidity sensing element that can be excited by low-voltage microscopic currents from solid-state electronic instrumentation, is physically sturdy, and is not affected by fingerprints or dirty environments. The element consists of a first electron conductive electrode, a porous coating of dielectric, minute particles of electron conductive material deposited in the interstices of the dielectric, a second electron conductive electrode pervious to moisture vapor, and an ion-forming material in the dielectric that reduces the porosity of the dielectric.
• The preferred embodiment of the humidity sensing element is made by anodizing a commercially pure aluminum first electrode to form the dielectric coating, depositing nickel particles in the interstices of the anodized layer, sealing the anodized layer, and forming a second nickel electrode on the sealed anodized layer. The method of manufacturing the element includes these steps, as well as optimizing the thickness of the anodized layer and the nickel deposits to achieve a linear relationship between the impedance of the element and the relative humidity of the surrounding atmosphere.
• The humidity sensing element functions by combining capacitance, which increases linearly with the number of water vapor molecules in the dielectric, and resistance, which increases with temperature, to produce an impedance that varies inversely and linearly with the relative humidity of the atmosphere. The element is suitable for use in typical textile mill environments and can be excited by a 10 Hz AC voltage to optimize the linearity of the impedance-humidity relationship.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a motor assembly with a force transmission structure comprising a drive plate and a shaft. The drive plate has a mounting hole with at least three interconnected sections, and the shaft has a toothed portion with at least three teeth that fit into the sections of the mounting hole, allowing the shaft to rotate with the drive plate.
* The drive plate includes a coupling with a greater depth than the body, and the mounting hole is formed in the coupling. The coupling also has buffer holes between the sections of the mounting hole to aid in molding and reduce distortion.
* The motor assembly includes a gear train with a worm, worm gear, and a damper that connects the worm gear to the drive plate. The damper has slots that receive the protrusions on the drive plate, allowing the drive plate to be rotated by the worm gear.
* The three-tooth design of the shaft and mounting hole provides a stable rotation of the shaft, reducing vibration and noise. The use of plastic for the drive plate also helps to absorb vibration and reduce noise in the gear train.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver. The system comprises an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem, and a baseband subsystem. The radio frequency subsystem includes a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator, while the baseband subsystem includes a free running counter coupled to the high frequency oscillator and the low frequency oscillator.

• The free running counter provides a mobile time reference to the system and has a wake mode and a sleep mode. During the wake mode, the free running counter uses the high frequency oscillator to generate the mobile time reference, and during the sleep mode, the free running counter uses the low frequency oscillator to maintain the mobile time reference.

• The present invention also provides a method of generating a mobile time reference. The method includes providing a high frequency clock, providing a low frequency clock, generating a mobile time reference using the high frequency clock, maintaining the mobile time reference using the low frequency clock when the high frequency clock is not available, and continuing to generate the mobile time reference using the high frequency clock when the high frequency clock is again available.

• The low frequency clock is phase locked to the high frequency clock, and an estimate of the drift and bias of the low frequency clock is made using a Kalman estimation. During the step of maintaining the mobile time reference, the mobile time reference is updated using the cycles of the low frequency clock counted when the high frequency clock is not available and the estimated drift/bias of the low frequency clock.

• The mobile time reference includes a clock-phase signal, a chip-counter, a slot-counter, and a frame-counter. The mobile time reference is provided to a multipath monitor and a multipath radio signal recovery circuit in the WCDMA modem of the portable transceiver.

• The present invention provides a wideband spread spectrum multipath signal detector, identification mechanism, and multipath monitoring technique that monitors signal strength from a plethora of asynchronous transmitters within a network in the presence of a moving time base, slotted operations, and effects of the mobile radio channel.

• The fast wakeup mechanism recovers multiple hypotheses in parallel to arrive quickly at a time base that can initiate subsequent demodulation of the spread spectrum signal, thus reducing power consumption and minimizing duty cycle of the slotted mode operations.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a protective helmet with a custom-fitted liner assembly between the outer shell and the wearer's head.
* The liner assembly consists of multiple layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets with an array of pockets that can deform to conform to the wearer's head.
* The layers are arranged in a superposed, contacting relationship without the need for the pockets to be in register with each other, simplifying the manufacturing process.
* The open and unfilled pockets allow the liner to conform to the contours of the wearer's head, reducing the tendency for the helmet to shift position.
* The liner can be custom-fitted to the wearer's head by heating the sheets, placing the liner between the outer shell and the wearer's head, and allowing it to cool and solidify.
* The custom-fitting process can be repeated to accommodate changes in head size, such as from changes in hair length or bumps on the head.
* The liner is simple and inexpensive to manufacture, does not require drawstrings or trimming, and resists the tendency to shift position on the wearer's head.
* The invention provides an individually fitted helmet liner that can be rapidly and simply fitted to a wearer's head and refitted to accommodate changed head sizes.
* The helmet liner fulfills the objects of the invention, including providing a simple, inexpensive, and adjustable custom-fitted liner assembly.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a multiorifice structure and a method of fabrication, particularly a multiorifice structure spray disc for use in an automotive fuel injector valve. The prior art methods of making such structures, such as drilling, punching, or photoetching, are impractical or difficult to achieve the desired uniformity and cost-effectiveness.

• The disclosed multiorifice structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods interspaced with cylindrically shaped members, where each successive layer of rods is disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly. The fused assembly is then cut into thin wafers, and the interstices formed between the fused layers of rods and the cylindrical members form a plurality of angularly disposed passageways.

• The thickness of the wafer is determined by the effective aperture of the interstices and is sufficient to impart a directional component to the fluid passing through the interstices, parallel to the angular displacement of the rods. The triangular-shaped orifices are more effective in atomizing the exiting fluid compared to circular orifices, due to the greater distortion of the exiting fluid stream.

• The method of fabrication involves twisting rods around a central core rod and sheathing them in cylindrical members, with each successive layer of rods being twisted at a greater angle. The composite structure is then fused or sintered to form an integral assembly, which is then sliced to produce the multiorifice structures.

• To facilitate the fusion of the rods and cylindrical members, they can be coated with a thin layer of material having a lower melting temperature than the materials of the rods and cylindrical members. This coating can be applied by various methods, such as electroplating, dipping, or vapor deposition.

• The invention is not limited to the specific configuration or method of manufacture described, and those skilled in the art could conceive of alternate embodiments, such as using cylindrical members of different shapes or replacing the single layer of rods with rods having non-circular cross-sections or multiple layers of rods between the cylindrical members.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention provides a method of fabricating a semiconductor device with an LDD structure by forming an insulating layer on the gate electrode and using it as a mask for ion implantation.
* The invention also uses a conductive or polycrystalline semiconductor layer on the gate sidewall as a mask for ion implantation, which allows for better control of the width of the sidewall portion.
* The invention utilizes silicidation of the gate electrode and/or source/drain regions to reduce resistance and prevent hot carrier degradation.
* The invention makes the low-concentration source/drain region amorphous by ion implantation, allowing for shallow junctions and device miniaturization.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to an improved end-user interface for Internet-protocol (IP) telephone communication. Conventional IP telephones require high-performance PCs with speech coding and decoding capabilities, which are expensive and inconvenient for users.
* The invention provides an enhanced radio telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as an IP telephone. The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder that allows it to be used with a low-performance PC, reducing cost and speech delay.
* The enhanced radio telephone can selectively operate as either a conventional radio telephone or an IP telephone. It can be connected to the PC via a cable or wireless connection, and IP-telephone control can be initiated from either the PC or the radio telephone.

* In alternative embodiments, the enhanced radio telephone is also used for wireless data communication to carry IP speech. The PC is not required to perform speech coding and decoding, further reducing the system's complexity and cost.
* The invention provides an improved IP telephone that is more convenient, economical, and efficient compared to conventional IP telephony systems. The enhanced radio telephone handset is comfortable for speech conversation and reduces echo problems.
* The invention can be implemented in various ways, depending on the cost and performance requirements of the application. The described embodiments are provided for illustration, and numerous equivalent embodiments are contemplated.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention relates to devices for producing electrical power, pressurized water or other useful work from surface waves on a water body.
* The invention uses one or more gas-filled submerged containers that expand and contract in response to overhead wave-induced pressure changes, producing useful work.
* The invention overcomes limitations of prior art devices by using partial evacuation or atmospheric venting, surface floating bodies, and other techniques to enhance energy capture.
* The invention can be oriented in various ways to capture both hydrostatic and hydrokinetic wave energy, and can be adjusted in depth to optimize performance.
* The invention can use various mechanisms, such as leveraged connecting means and multi-staged drive cylinders, to increase stroke and energy capture.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to the mounting of blades for a scraped surface heat exchanger onto the central drive shaft. Scraped surface heat exchangers are widely used in industry, such as in the processing of foodstuffs, and typically include a central drive shaft that rotates inside a cylindrical outer tube.
• Blades are hingedly connected to the central drive shaft to help mix the material and/or scrape the inside surface of the outer tube. The blades are typically mounted to the drive shaft using a pin-type connection, which can be cumbersome and require the user to hold the blades in place during installation, especially in the case of a vertically arranged heat exchanger.
• The invention provides a blade with L-shaped locking tracks on both sides that interact with the mounting pins to facilitate the mounting of the blade onto the drive shaft. The locking tracks have an entry track and an intermediate track that allow the blade to be slid onto the pins and then locked in place, preventing the blade from falling off during installation.
• The use of locking tracks on both sides of the blade helps preserve the structural rigidity of the blade and allows for acceptable performance even as the blades and pins wear over time. The different widths of the entry tracks also ensure that the blade is installed with the correct orientation.
• The blade can be slid onto the pins at an installation angle and then rotated to a shallow angle for insertion into the outer tube of the heat exchanger. Even if the blade is left free to pivot, the locking tracks will prevent it from sliding off the pins, particularly in the case of a vertically arranged heat exchanger.
• The invention provides a method for mounting a blade to a scraped surface heat exchanger drive shaft by pivotal connection with a mounting pin, using tracks on both sides of the blade to lock the blade against longitudinal movement in one direction while permitting pivoting movement relative to the drive shaft.
• The invention is not limited to the specific details of construction and arrangement of components described, and those skilled in the art will appreciate that the invention can be embodied in various ways and carried out in different manners.
• The invention provides a significant benefit in vertically arranged scraped surface heat exchangers, where the blades can be positioned at the installation angle, slid onto the pins, and then slid downwardly along the pins until reaching the final position

<summary>
* The invention relates to a process and an apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in the cigarette magazine of a cigarette-production and/or cigarette-packaging machine. Cigarette production and/or packaging machines often have a cigarette store where cigarettes can end up being located transversely, blocking individual shafts or shaft groups beneath the storage part.
* The detection process uses at least one optical checking element, such as a camera, to scan an image of a plurality of cigarettes in the cigarette magazine, which is then evaluated by an image-processing device. If the scanned image deviates from a reference image and/or reference values, an error signal is produced.
* The detection apparatus includes an optical checking element, an image-processing device, and means to produce an error signal if the scanned image deviates from a reference image and/or reference values. This allows for the detection of transversely located cigarettes and other defective cigarettes.
* The elimination process involves detecting a defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarette and, in reaction, actuating an ejecting unit arranged in the region of the magazine to eject a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.
* The elimination apparatus has at least one, or a plurality of, adjacent ejecting units arranged in the region of the magazine, intended for ejecting a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to an ejecting unit.
* The front and rear walls of the ejecting unit are of different sizes and contours, with the rear wall being greater than the front wall by at least the width of one cigarette, to avoid jamming of partially gripped cigarettes.
* The cigarette magazine has a storage part and shaft groups arranged beneath it, with the cigarettes passing through a top opening and moving downwards under the force of gravity.
* The camera scans an image of the cigarette magazine over its entire width, and the image-processing device evaluates the scanned image, comparing it to a reference image or reference values to detect errors.
* The ejected cigarettes are fed to a tobacco-recycling circuit, where the tobacco is recovered and reused in cigarette production, minimizing waste.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a device for interconnecting a high voltage cable with an apparatus or another high voltage cable. It provides a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections, resulting in advantages such as factory pretesting, reduction of installation time and cost, and simplified field testing.
* The interface between the cable end and any accessory, between two cable ends, or between two apparatus can be achieved through three different principles: inner cone concept, outer cone concept, and no cone or slight inner cone concept. The outer cone concept has the advantage of separating the cable connection further from the apparatus it is connected to.
* The invention includes various applications such as SF6 terminals, transformer terminals, outdoor terminals, straight-through joints, and transition joints between dry and oil-filled cables. These applications offer advantages like compact design, lower material and installation cost, and standardization.
* The essential characteristic of the invention is the outer surface configuration of the rigid insulator, which should have a conical interface surface with an angle between 15° and 45° between the longitudinal axis and the boundary surface.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a fixing mechanism for a tool used in machining, which comprises a tool, its frame, and a tool holder in the frame of a machine tool. The fixing mechanism uses a curved connecting surface between the tool frame and the tool holder, which allows for a simple and secure mounting and dismounting of the tool.
* The curved connecting surface can be on either the tool frame or the tool holder, and the other part has a corresponding curved surface. The mechanism also includes contact surfaces perpendicular to the mounting direction that transmit the machining forces, and a clamp system that applies a force to hold the tool in place.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention provides methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits at high efficiencies and with low quantities of radiated energy (EMI) by utilizing switching regulator circuits with multiple circuit paths carrying electric current in opposite directions to cancel out the radiated noise.
* The invention also includes additional terminal lines that act to sink any electromagnetic interference (EMI) generated in the outermost paths that are actively coupled to the circuit.
</summary>

<summary>
* The source document describes a power system that includes a battery with multiple cells. The system includes a controller that causes the cells to acquire charge for a period of time such that the voltages of the cells are approximately equal at the end of the period.
* The rate at which charge is acquired by the cells may be different among at least some of the cells for at least a determined portion of the period of time. The algorithms for determining the charge times and balancing the cells are described in detail, and the document suggests that these techniques can be used to reduce the time spent rebalancing and charging vehicle batteries.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter that converts an AC input voltage to a constant DC voltage, providing a lamp power supply with constant brightness, no low or high frequency flicker, and no electromagnetic radiation.
• The converter includes various components such as input protection, EMI filter, rectifier, converter, output filter, and control circuits to achieve the desired output.
• The invention can be used in various applications, including bus AC to DC converter, PFC converter, computer power supply, TV power supply, and more, to prevent myopia and protect people's health.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention provides a system to control daylight and artificial illumination and sun glare in a space. The system comprises a central processor, a dimming panel, photosensor interfaces, and wall stations for manual control.
• The system controls the electric lights based on a closed-loop algorithm using preset lighting scenes. The dimming level of each lamp is selected from one of the presets to achieve the desired illumination profile and compensate for daylight.
• The system also controls the window treatments based on a closed-loop algorithm to maintain the desired illumination profile and minimize sun glare. The system adjusts the window treatments when the light level is outside a predefined dead-band.

• The system can operate in two modes: one controlling only the electric lights and the other controlling both the electric lights and the window treatments. The system can also control only the window treatments based on the available daylight.
• The system employs a variable control setpoint or threshold to address the glare control problem. The setpoint is varied based on the sun angle, which is determined using an astronomical time clock.
• The system can adjust the dead-band thresholds or the photosensor gain to compensate for the decrease in illumination with the sun angle. This allows the system to differentiate between clear sky and overcast conditions.

• The system can automatically detect and update the component of the photosensor reading caused by the electric lighting at night. This component is subtracted from the daytime reading to determine the daylight component.
• The system can automatically recalibrate based on occupant input, resulting in increased occupant satisfaction. The system also has the potential to maximize daylight savings by closing the window treatments only during glare incidents or when the sunlight illumination near the windows exceeds a preset value.
• The system can be used to control the lighting in a space, where the illumination sources include both daylight and artificial light, and to reduce or eliminate sun glare through openings in the space.
</summary>

<summary>
* Before September 2001, there were significant vulnerabilities in aviation security, including weaknesses in passenger and baggage screening, access control, and protection of air traffic control systems. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was created to address these vulnerabilities, and it has taken major steps to improve aviation security since then.

* TSA met several key deadlines set by the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA), such as deploying federal passenger screeners and using explosives detection systems to screen checked baggage. However, TSA experienced some difficulties in meeting these deadlines and achieving its goals.

* To strengthen access control, TSA is pursuing initiatives such as the Transportation Workers Identification Card (TWIC) program and the Computer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System (CAPPS II). These initiatives aim to leverage technology and information to improve security.

* While TSA has focused on passenger and baggage screening, vulnerabilities remain in areas such as air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security. TSA is working to address these vulnerabilities, but progress has been limited.

* Sustaining the aviation security advancements will require TSA to address several long-term challenges, including risk management, funding, coordination, strategic human capital management, and building a results-oriented organization.

* TSA has taken steps to implement a risk management approach, but it needs to complete the development of its assessment tools and use them to prepare action plans for specific modes of transportation and transportation security in general.

* Funding challenges include paying for the installation of explosives detection equipment and ensuring continued investment in transportation research and development. Coordination with federal, state, and local agencies, as well as the aviation community, is also crucial.

* TSA faces the challenge of strategically managing its large workforce and ensuring that it has the right skills and training to perform its duties effectively. Building a results-oriented culture within the new Department of Homeland Security is also important for sustaining enhanced aviation security.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sections 4911 and 162(e) have different definitions of lobbying. LDA covers only federal lobbying, while the IRC definitions cover lobbying at the federal, state, and local levels.
* LDA does not cover grassroots lobbying, but the IRC definitions do. The IRC definitions also cover a broader range of executive branch officials for contacts on legislative matters, while LDA covers a broader range of executive branch officials for contacts on nonlegislative matters.
* LDA has 19 exceptions to its definition of lobbying, mostly for technical clarifications, while IRC section 4911 has two significant exceptions that could allow organizations to exclude a substantial amount of lobbying expenses.
* The choice of definition can affect whether an organization must register under LDA and what information it must report, as the definitions cover different activities and contacts.
* Of the organizations that lobbied on their own behalf and filed reports under LDA from July through December 1997, most used the LDA definition, while those using the IRC section 162(e) definition had the highest mean and median expenses reported.
* Options for addressing the differences between the definitions include harmonizing them, eliminating the authorization for organizations to use the IRC definitions for LDA reporting, or requiring organizations using an IRC definition to report only federal-level lobbying expenses.
