• Education agreed with GAO's findings and recommendations and discussed its efforts to address longer-term and structural issues that hinder the efficient and effective performance of FSA and the department.

• Education said it will work to refine the unit cost measure, establish measurable goals and milestones for systems integration, develop new performance measures for program integrity, and integrate human capital management into its broader strategies for the department.
</summary>

<summary>
* The National Institutes of Health (NIH) made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds, which supported an estimated 54,000 full-time equivalent (FTE) jobs.
* NIH grantees reported using the Recovery Act funding to purchase research supplies and equipment, as well as to provide scientific training to healthcare professionals.
* The selected principal investigators reported preliminary results from their Recovery Act-funded research, which could contribute to future scientific developments in preventive medicine, early disease detection, and medical therapies.
</summary>

<summary>
* Transit-oriented development is a compact, mixed-use, and walkable neighborhood located near transit. Various stakeholders, including local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, local governments, private developers, and lenders, play important roles in the planning and implementation of transit-oriented development.

* Factors that can support transit-oriented development include market demand for real estate, availability of large parcels of land for development, resident support for transit and dense development, and efficient access to jobs and activity centers. Factors that can hinder transit-oriented development include higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance such projects, lengthy or discretionary local approval processes, lack of local support, and unattractive physical features around transit stations.

* Local governments can use various policies to encourage transit-oriented development, such as creating zoning regulations supportive of transit-oriented development, developing area plans to provide guidance and resolve contentious issues, and making targeted investments in infrastructure around transit stations.

* FTA evaluates several factors related to transit-oriented development when reviewing transit projects for potential New Starts funding, but these factors make up only a small percentage of all the factors considered. The actual amount of transit-oriented development and ridership performance of the transit lines can vary from FTA's pre-construction evaluation and rating.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Social Security Act of 1935 gave workers the right to review their earnings records with the Social Security Administration (SSA) to ensure accuracy. In 1988, the SSA introduced the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) to better enable workers to review their earnings records and obtain benefit estimates.
* According to the SSA, fewer than 2% of workers who pay Social Security taxes request these statements each year. The PEBES legislation requires the SSA to begin sending the statements to eligible workers who have not requested them.
* The SSA's goals in providing the PEBES are to better inform the public about available benefits, assist workers in planning their financial future, and ensure the accuracy of Social Security earnings records. Accurate earnings records are important because they determine a worker's eligibility and benefit amount.
* The PEBES benefit estimates are intended to help workers plan for their financial future, but they may over- or understate benefits for certain individuals due to the SSA's assumptions and methodology. The SSA has included descriptions of circumstances that may result in different benefit amounts.

* The public's overall reaction to receiving the unsolicited PEBES has been consistently favorable, with older individuals reacting more favorably than younger individuals. The SSA has revised the statement in response to feedback from the public and its own employees.
* However, the current PEBES still provides too much information, which may overwhelm the reader, and presents the information in a way that undermines its usefulness. These weaknesses are attributed to the process the SSA used to develop the PEBES.
* The PEBES lacks an obvious purpose, attractive and functional design, and easy-to-understand explanations. The message from the Commissioner of Social Security does not clearly explain why the SSA is providing the statement.
* Comments from the public, SSA employees, and benefit experts indicate that the PEBES contains too much information and is too complex. The statement's structure is not clear, and the explanations are scattered throughout the document.
* The SSA has missed opportunities to improve the PEBES, such as conducting formal comprehension tests and collecting detailed feedback from its front-line workers. The SSA is focused on reducing printing costs rather than considering all factors that would ensure the PEBES is a cost-effective document.
* The GAO recommends that the SSA rev

<summary>
• The Social Security Administration (SSA) administers two disability programs: Disability Insurance (DI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI). Both programs use the same definition of disability for initial entitlement.
• DI is an insurance program that helps replace earnings lost due to disability, while SSI provides a standard minimum level of income for individuals with disabilities who have limited income and assets.
• Concurrent beneficiaries receive benefits from both the DI and SSI programs. They comprise about 14% of SSA's disability population and are more likely to have mental impairments and be female.
• Concurrent beneficiaries who work earn less than SSI beneficiaries who work, and they do not take advantage of most of the work incentives available to them under the two programs.
• SSA's guidance for administering the DI and SSI programs is not well integrated, making it difficult for staff to serve concurrent beneficiaries effectively and adjust their benefits in a timely manner.
• SSA has taken steps to address the challenges in serving concurrent beneficiaries, such as creating a new employment support representative position and developing a new computer system to collect information about the monthly earnings of all DI beneficiaries who are working.
• Concurrent beneficiaries need a better understanding of how work activity affects their benefits under both the DI and SSI programs to make informed decisions about their employment.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Stafford Act authorizes the federal government to assist in disaster relief and recovery efforts. As of June 2006, nearly $88 billion was appropriated through four emergency supplemental appropriations for relief and recovery efforts related to the recent Gulf Coast hurricanes.
* FEMA uses the Disaster Relief Fund to assist relief and recovery efforts, and it issues mission assignments to other federal agencies to support these efforts. FEMA's weekly reports to Congress on the use of these funds have limited usefulness from a governmentwide perspective.
* The federal government does not have a framework or mechanisms in place to collect and consolidate information from the 23 federal agencies that have directly received funding for hurricane relief efforts and report on this information. This makes it difficult for decision makers to determine how much federal funding has been spent and by whom.

* FEMA's reported obligations for mission assignments are often overstated compared to the actual obligations incurred by the performing agencies. This is because FEMA records the entire amount of the mission assignment as an obligation, while the performing agency only records an obligation when it actually obligates funds to carry out the work.
* FEMA's reported expenditures are often understated compared to the actual expenditures made by the performing agencies. This is because FEMA does not recognize reimbursements to other agencies as expenditures until it has received and approved the billing from the performing agency, which can take months.
* Some performing agencies have not provided billing documentation that meets FEMA's requirements to support their reimbursements for work performed on mission assignments, resulting in FEMA "charging back" about $267 million from these agencies.

* To improve the information in FEMA's weekly reports, the report recommends that FEMA explain the limitations of its reported obligations and expenditures, periodically request and include actual obligation and expenditure data from agencies performing mission assignments, and reiterate its policies on supporting documentation and timely billings.
* To help ensure better accountability and transparency, the report recommends that OMB establish a framework for governmentwide reporting on the status of hurricane-related funding, either by collecting and consolidating the information itself or designating another appropriate agency to do so.
* The report concludes that without consistent, reliable, and timely governmentwide information on the use of this funding, the agencies and the Congress could lose

<summary>
• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has the authority to authorize all Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) operations in the national airspace, including military, public, and civil operations.
• The FAA has a phased approach to integrating UAS into the national airspace, including an accommodation phase, an integration phase, and an evolution phase, and has taken steps to facilitate UAS operations through test sites and a proposed rule for small UAS operations.
</summary>

<summary>
* Afghanistan has different development, security, and infrastructure needs compared to Iraq. The CERP program in Afghanistan has evolved over time, with more complex and costly projects being undertaken.
* Management and execution of the CERP program is the responsibility of officials at various levels, including CJTF-101 headquarters, brigades, and Provincial Reconstruction Teams (PRTs). DOD is required to provide Congress with quarterly reports on the source, allocation, and use of CERP funds.
* DOD faces significant challenges in providing adequate management and oversight of CERP due to an insufficient number of trained personnel to execute and manage the program. Headquarters and brigade-level personnel have expressed a need for additional personnel to perform essential CERP functions.
* Inadequate training has led to common mistakes in CERP contracts and project files, which can increase the department's cost risk and result in projects that do not meet their goals or objectives.
* DOD and USAID participate in various mechanisms to facilitate coordination, but lack a common database that would provide greater visibility on all U.S. government development projects in Afghanistan.
* USAID has initiated a project to develop a unified database to capture reliable and verified data for all development projects in Afghanistan, but plans are preliminary and a number of questions remain.
* The expected surge in troops and increase in funding for Afghanistan heightens the need for an adequate number of trained personnel to execute and oversee CERP, as well as a centralized project-development database.
* GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense and the Administrator of USAID collaborate to create a centralized project-development database and that the Secretary of Defense ensure adequate staff and training for CERP personnel.
</summary>

<summary>
* Solar energy can be used to heat, cool, and power homes and businesses through various technologies that convert sunlight into usable energy. Examples include photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water.
* Solar energy technology advancement activities range from basic research to commercialization, with an emphasis on applied research and demonstration.

* In fiscal years 2010 and 2011, six federal agencies undertook 65 initiatives that supported solar energy technology, at least in part. Over half of these initiatives supported solar projects exclusively.
* Of the 4,996 total projects active under the 65 initiatives, 1,506 (30%) were solar projects, and 3,490 (70%) were not solar projects.

* The initiatives supported different types of solar energy technologies, including photovoltaic and concentrated solar power technologies, through multiple technology advancement activities.
* The initiatives provided funding to universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal laboratories and researchers, primarily through grants and contracts.

* Agency officials reported obligating around $2.6 billion for the solar projects in these initiatives in fiscal years 2010 and 2011, with over 90% of the funds obligated by the Department of Energy.
* The 65 solar-related initiatives are fragmented across six agencies, but agency officials reported a number of coordination activities to avoid duplication.
* While many initiatives overlapped in their key characteristics, agency officials reported engaging in various coordination activities to leverage resources and define common outcomes, which can help address fragmentation, overlap, and duplication.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) has determined that servicemembers must be protected to survive and conduct effective military operations, and has developed new, lightweight individual protective equipment to replace the current protective suits.
* However, DOD's risk assessment process is flawed and unreliable, and its inventory management practices have contributed to increased risk, with inaccurate data and the inability to determine the expiration dates of protective equipment.
</summary>

<summary>
* Program evaluations are systematic studies that use research methods to assess program performance and effectiveness. Evaluation is closely related to performance measurement and can provide valuable insights to program managers, policymakers, and the public.

* The GPRA Modernization Act of 2010 (GPRAMA) established an expectation that evidence would have a greater role in agency decision making. GPRAMA also charged the Performance Improvement Council with facilitating agencies' exchange of successful practices and development of tools to strengthen performance management.

* Our 2017 survey found no change government-wide in managers' access to evaluations since 2013, with about 40% reporting having access to recent evaluations. Managers who had evaluations reported that they contributed to understanding program performance and assessing effectiveness.

* Factors that facilitated evaluation use included leadership support, staff involvement, and evaluation relevance to decision makers. Lack of resources to implement evaluation findings was the most commonly reported barrier to use.

* Engaging stakeholders, building a body of evidence, and having written evaluation policies and standards can help ensure evaluations are relevant and used. Congressional support through requests or mandates can also facilitate evaluation use.

* Agencies are encouraged to develop annual evaluation plans in consultation with stakeholders to ensure evaluations address important questions and inform decision making. OMB should direct agencies to prepare such plans.

* Evaluations can help measure complex or costly forms of performance and identify reasons for changes in program performance. However, their use appears to be more internally oriented than externally focused on informing the public.

* Evaluation expertise is needed to plan, conduct, and interpret evaluations, but program staff also need sufficient knowledge to understand and translate evaluation results into steps toward program improvement.

* Developing a body of evidence, rather than relying on a single study, and engaging stakeholders throughout the evaluation process can help ensure evaluations are used effectively in management and policy decisions.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Rehabilitation Act defines disability and provides special hiring authorities for people with disabilities in the federal workforce. Executive Order 13548 requires federal agencies to develop plans for hiring and retaining employees with disabilities, and designate a senior-level official to be accountable for meeting the goals of the order.
• However, many agency plans do not meet the criteria identified by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) as essential to becoming a model employer of people with disabilities. OPM needs to expedite the development of mandatory training programs for hiring managers and human resource personnel, and assess the accuracy of the self-reported disability data to ensure the federal government can effectively measure progress towards the executive order's goals.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is a part of the Department of the Interior and manages about 270 million acres of public lands in the United States. BLM has been developing the Automated Land and Mineral Record System (ALMRS)/Modernization project to automate its land and mineral records and case processing activities, as well as provide information to support land and resource management activities.

• The ALMRS/Modernization project consists of three main components: the ALMRS Initial Operating Capability (ALMRS IOC), the Geographic Coordinate Data Base (GCDB), and the modernization of BLM's computer and telecommunications infrastructure. The project has faced some challenges, including cost overruns and tight development schedules, and BLM has taken actions to address these issues.

• The report recommends that BLM ensure the entire ALMRS/Modernization system is thoroughly stress tested before deployment to ensure it can successfully process the expected workloads during peak operating conditions. BLM has agreed with this recommendation and plans to conduct the necessary stress testing.
</summary>

<summary>
• The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is an independent organization affiliated with the United Nations that establishes and administers safeguards to verify the peaceful use of nuclear energy. IAEA has taken steps to strengthen its safeguards by more aggressively seeking assurances that countries are not pursuing clandestine nuclear programs, including conducting short-notice inspections, collecting environmental samples, and using surveillance systems.
• Despite these efforts, IAEA faces limitations that impact its ability to draw conclusions about whether a country is developing a clandestine nuclear weapons program, such as not having unfettered inspection rights and facing practical challenges in accessing certain sites. Additionally, more than half of the countries that have signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty have not yet brought the Additional Protocol into force, which would give IAEA expanded inspection rights.
</summary>

<summary>
* The public faces a high risk that critical services could be severely disrupted by the Year 2000 computing crisis. Key economic sectors, such as information and telecommunications, banking and finance, and transportation, are at risk of being affected. The global nature of the problem also poses a significant risk, as many countries are behind the United States in addressing the issue.

* The federal government is making slow progress in fixing its systems, with only 40% of mission-critical systems reported as compliant as of May 1998. Agencies have uneven progress, with some significantly behind schedule and at high risk of not fixing their systems in time.

* Governmentwide priorities in fixing systems have not been established, and business continuity and contingency planning across the government has been inadequate. OMB's assessment of federal Year 2000 progress is predominantly based on unverified agency reports, and end-to-end testing responsibilities have not been defined.

* State and local governments also face a major risk of Year 2000-induced failures to the many vital services they provide. Recent surveys indicate that much remains to be completed, and many states are not expected to be compliant until the last quarter of 1999.

* Data exchanges between federal, state, and local governments must also be addressed, as they are critical for the transfer of information. However, much work remains to ensure that these exchanges will be Year 2000 compliant.

* To address these challenges, greater leadership and partnerships are essential. Federal, state, and local efforts must increase substantially to ensure that major service disruptions do not occur.

* In summary, the Year 2000 computing crisis poses a significant risk to critical services, and substantial work remains to be done at all levels of government to address the issue and ensure continuity of operations.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Information Quality Act (IQA) required the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to develop guidelines for federal agencies to ensure the quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of information they disseminate. Agencies were required to establish administrative mechanisms to allow affected persons to seek and obtain correction of information.
* OMB provided assistance and direction to agencies in developing their IQA guidelines, but did not follow up with many independent agencies to ensure they met the IQA requirements. As a result, 44 out of 91 independent agencies examined did not have IQA guidelines posted on their websites.
* The number of IQA correction requests declined from over 24,000 in fiscal year 2003 to 62 in fiscal year 2004, largely due to some agencies no longer classifying simple or administrative errors as IQA requests. Substantive requests, which required more time and resources to address, increased as a proportion of total requests.
* Businesses, trade groups, and other profit-oriented organizations filed the majority of appeals of agency decisions on IQA requests, and these appeals were less likely to result in information changes compared to appeals from other types of organizations or individuals.
* Agencies and OMB do not have mechanisms in place to track the costs or workload associated with implementing IQA, but evidence suggests that addressing IQA requests and appeals can be time-consuming and resource-intensive, particularly for substantive requests.
</summary>

<summary>
* Both mutual fund companies and banks are financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and channel them back to the economy. Banks generally use deposits to make loans or invest in debt securities, while mutual funds invest in securities, primarily bonds and stocks.
* The relative importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining, as large businesses and households have been replacing bank loans with securities markets. Securitization has also reduced the dependence on bank credit, with banks and thrifts providing the initial financing and the securities market becoming the ultimate source of financing.
* The growth of mutual funds has had a significant impact on bank deposits, with the amount of money in mutual funds rising by almost $1.2 trillion since 1989, while bank deposits declined by $89 billion. However, the full impact of mutual funds on deposits is difficult to quantify, as it includes both direct withdrawals and the diversion of new receipts that otherwise might have been placed in deposits.
* The movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds has not affected the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy, as both types of intermediaries generally invest a substantial portion of the funds they receive. Mutual funds' investments in securities have added liquidity to the securities markets, which may have made it easier for a broader range of borrowers to tap the securities-issuance markets.
* The availability of finance for different borrower sectors, such as residential, consumer, and business, could be disproportionally affected by the movement of funds out of bank deposits and into mutual funds, as mutual funds invest mainly in securities. However, all three sectors have increased their access to finance raised in the securities markets.
* Small businesses that are primarily dependent on small banks for their loans could experience reduced credit availability if their banks lose deposits to mutual funds. However, small banks may be able to fund existing and new loans by selling securities in their investment accounts.
* The channels of financing are varied, and a shift of customers' money from deposits into mutual funds need not reduce credit availability for any group of borrowers. The possibility of credit availability constraints for some borrowers from small banks remains, but it is not clear whether those circumstances currently exist.
* The Federal Reserve agreed that the report provides a timely review of the flow of funds between mutual funds and bank deposits and the effect of these flows on credit availability, and had no further comment on the

<summary>
• The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has primary responsibility for coordinating the nation's response to public health emergencies, including bioterrorism. HHS divisions, such as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), are pursuing major public health IT initiatives to strengthen the effectiveness of the public health infrastructure.

• While progress has been made, significant work remains to be done. Federal agencies face challenges in aligning their initiatives with the national health IT strategy, coordinating with state and local public health agencies, and implementing robust IT management practices.

• HHS has made progress in identifying and promoting the adoption of health care data and communication standards, but implementation challenges remain. Establishing mechanisms to ensure coordination and consensus among standards-setting initiatives is crucial for achieving interoperability.

• GAO recommends that HHS and DHS take actions to ensure their public health IT initiatives are aligned with the national health IT strategy and coordinated with state and local efforts, and that they continue to encourage the development and implementation of health care data and communication standards.
</summary>

<summary>
* The survey of the largest sponsors of defined-benefit (DB) pension plans reveals that they have made a number of revisions to their benefit offerings over the last 10 years, such as revising benefit formulas, converting some plans to hybrid plans, or freezing some of their plans. The majority of respondents reported that they had either increased the generosity of their DB plan formulas for bargaining unit employees or decreased the generosity for non-bargaining employees.
* The survey also found that the majority of respondents offered health benefits to active employees and retirees, but a significant number had decreased or eliminated the firm's share of the cost of providing health benefits for future retirees, especially for non-bargaining employees. Additionally, the survey indicates that the majority of respondents were not planning to make significant changes to their pension plans in the future, despite recent legislation and accounting changes.
</summary>

<summary>
* The United States admits tens of thousands of refugees each year, which can have a significant impact on the communities where they are resettled, particularly if relevant state and local stakeholders are not consulted before the refugees arrive.
* Refugee resettlement programs are designed to help refugees become employed as quickly as possible, which can limit the services they receive to achieve long-term self-sufficiency and integration.
* The federal government has recognized the importance of refugee integration, but does not currently measure it as a program outcome or widely disseminate information on effective strategies for facilitating integration.
</summary>

<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 established the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) to provide government-guaranteed flood insurance and reduce federal costs for repairing flood damage.
* NFIP offers subsidized and full-risk premium rates, but many rates do not reflect the full risk of flooding, exposing taxpayers to potential losses.
* Increasing premium rates to fully reflect flood risks could reduce costs to taxpayers but may decrease participation in the program.
* NFIP has borrowed from the Treasury to pay claims during catastrophic loss years, and mitigation efforts could help reduce flood damage and taxpayer exposure.
* Increasing participation in NFIP, particularly in low-risk areas, could help diversify the risk pool and lower rates, but must be carefully implemented.
* The private market provides limited flood insurance coverage, and encouraging private sector participation could transfer some federal risk, but may also raise affordability concerns.
* Congress needs to address NFIP's financial and operational challenges, including charging accurate premium rates, funding mitigation efforts, and improving FEMA's management and oversight.
* GAO has identified four public policy goals for evaluating the federal role in providing natural catastrophe insurance, which can guide NFIP reform efforts.
* FEMA needs to address management issues, such as strategic planning, human capital planning, and information technology, to improve NFIP's stability and efficiency.
</summary>

<summary>
* Section 287(g) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) authorizes ICE to enter into agreements with state and local law enforcement agencies to perform certain immigration enforcement functions. The 287(g) program has grown rapidly in recent years, with ICE receiving increased funding to support it.
* ICE has not clearly documented the objectives of the 287(g) program, leading to inconsistencies in how participating agencies use their 287(g) authority. The MOAs with participating agencies lack specificity on the use of 287(g) authority and the nature and extent of ICE supervision.
* ICE has not defined what program information should be tracked or ensured consistent data collection and reporting by participating agencies. This limits ICE's ability to monitor program implementation and ensure adherence to objectives.
* ICE has not developed performance measures to assess the effectiveness of the 287(g) program in achieving its intended results. Developing such measures would provide ICE with a basis for determining the program's success.
* ICE and participating agencies use program resources mainly for personnel, training, and equipment. ICE provides funding, while participating agencies also contribute resources such as officers and facilities.
* Participating agencies have reported benefits of the 287(g) program, including reduced crime and identifying repeat offenders. However, they have also reported concerns from their communities about potential misuse of 287(g) authority.
* The rapid growth of the 287(g) program has presented resource challenges for ICE, including limited supervision capacity. ICE is working to address these challenges, such as by considering alternative partnership programs that may better meet the needs of some applicants.
* Removing aliens who have committed serious crimes is important for public safety, but the lack of internal controls in the 287(g) program limits ICE's ability to ensure the program is achieving this objective. Addressing the identified issues could help ICE better manage the program.
</summary>

<summary>
* SEC oversees mutual funds primarily through its Office of Compliance Inspections and Examinations (OCIE), Division of Investment Management, and Division of Enforcement. OCIE examines mutual funds to evaluate their compliance with federal securities laws and assess the effectiveness of their compliance control systems. The Division of Investment Management administers the securities laws affecting funds and advisers, while the Division of Enforcement investigates and prosecutes violations of securities laws related to mutual funds.

* SEC regulates mutual funds under various federal securities laws, including the Investment Company Act of 1940, which requires mutual funds to register with SEC and imposes requirements on their operation and structure. The Investment Advisers Act requires mutual fund advisers to register with SEC and prohibits them from engaging in fraudulent, deceptive, or manipulative practices.

* SEC has made significant changes to its mutual fund examination program, including placing a higher priority on sweep and cause examinations and a lower priority on routine examinations. SEC also plans to provide more continuous and in-depth oversight of the largest mutual funds and is considering the development of a surveillance program to support its oversight of all funds and advisers.

* SEC's revised examination approach offers potential advantages, but it also involves significant tradeoffs that raise important regulatory challenges for the agency, such as limiting its capacity to examine lower risk funds and conduct risk assessments of the industry within a reasonable time period.

* SEC integrates quality controls into its routine examinations, but it could benefit from additional controls to ensure that policies and procedures are being implemented effectively and consistently throughout SEC field offices. SEC does not require written examination plans or document supervisory review of work papers, and it does not periodically review completed examinations and work papers.

* SEC conducts broker-dealer oversight examinations to evaluate the adequacy of self-regulatory organization (SRO) activities, but these examinations provide limited information on the quality of SRO oversight and impose duplicative regulatory costs on the securities industry.

* SEC, NASD, and NYSE have developed guidance for examiners to use in assessing compliance by broker-dealers with mutual fund sales practice rules, and they periodically share information and coordinate their examination efforts. However, they generally do not provide copies of their written examination materials to each other.

* SEC, NASD, and NYSE have provided training to their broker-dealer examiners on mutual funds and other topics, but

<summary>
• The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) is an independent federal corporation established by the TVA Act to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley.
• TVA must design its rates to cover all costs but also keep rates as low as feasible, and it can borrow up to $30 billion.
• TVA's Board of Directors sets goals, policies, and rates, and approves the agency's strategic plan and budget.
• TVA plans to reduce its debt to about $22 billion by fiscal year 2023 through rate increases, limiting operating expense growth, and reducing capital expenditures.
• TVA's debt reduction plans and performance information are not reported in a manner consistent with GPRAMA requirements.
• Several factors could affect TVA's ability to meet its debt reduction goal, including regulatory pressures, changes in electricity demand, and technological innovations.
• TVA aims to eliminate its $6 billion in unfunded pension liabilities within 20 years, but the TVARS Rules do not ensure full funding of the pension plan.
• We recommend that TVA better document and communicate its goals to reduce debt and unfunded pension liabilities, and propose funding rules to ensure full pension plan funding.
• TVA agreed to incorporate more details in its performance plans and reports, but neither agreed nor disagreed to propose funding rules to ensure full pension plan funding.
</summary>

<summary>
* In the late 1970s, First City Bancorporation of Texas had a high concentration of loans to the energy industry in the Southwest United States. When the energy industry experienced financial difficulties in the early and mid-1980s, so did First City.
* In 1988, FDIC provided $970 million in open bank assistance to First City to recapitalize the bank. The assistance agreement did not include sufficient safeguards to ensure that the new bank management pursued a prudent business strategy or had the expertise and capabilities to manage the bank's activities.
* By 1990, First City's loan portfolios had deteriorated, and the bank experienced significant losses. In 1992, OCC determined that First City-Houston was insolvent, leading to the closure of the entire First City banking organization.
* FDIC's resolution of the failed First City banks in 1992 initially estimated a $500 million cost to the Bank Insurance Fund (BIF). However, the eventual sale of the banks in 1993 resulted in a surplus of about $60 million, which was later projected to exceed $200 million.
* The First City experience offers valuable lessons for FDIC and other regulators, including the importance of consulting with regulatory counterparts, incorporating appropriate safeguards in open bank assistance agreements, and ensuring that examination reports and workpapers provide clear and complete documentation of the bases for regulatory decisions.
* The First City resolution also highlights the changes in regulatory authorities and resolution options that have occurred since the 1980s, such as the introduction of bridge banks, the least-cost resolution requirement, and the cross-guarantee provisions.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was enacted to address concerns about the lack of adequate oversight and accountability for federal assistance provided to state and local governments. The act established the single audit concept, which replaced multiple grant audits with one audit of an entity as a whole, to promote sound financial management and effective internal control over federal awards.
• A recent study by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency (PCIE) found that a significant number of single audits had deficiencies, with 51% of the audits classified as having limited reliability or being unacceptable. The PCIE report recommended a three-pronged approach to improve single audit quality, including revising standards and guidance, establishing minimum training requirements for auditors, and enhancing disciplinary processes for unacceptable audits.
</summary>

<summary>
• Medicare is a federal health insurance program that covers hospital, physician, and other medical services for elderly and disabled beneficiaries. Claims are processed by a network of intermediaries and carriers, which are selected through a process that differs from most federal contracting.
• Medicare's contracting process has been criticized for lacking full and open competition, limiting the program's ability to benefit from efficiency and performance improvements. Proposals have been made to grant Medicare more flexibility in selecting and managing its contractors.
• Implementing contracting reforms would pose significant challenges for Medicare, including developing clear statements of work, integrating new contractors, and establishing effective performance evaluation criteria. An incremental approach would be prudent to avoid disrupting program services.

• The Social Security Act currently limits Medicare's ability to terminate underperforming contractors or offer financial incentives for high-quality performance. Removing these limitations could improve program management, but would require careful implementation to ensure coordination and avoid unintended consequences.
• Medicare has had some experience with functional contracting, where specific claims administration activities are handled by separate contractors. This approach could improve efficiency and performance, but also poses coordination challenges that would need to be addressed.
• Prior experiments with performance-based contracting for Medicare claims administration have had mixed results, raising concerns about the potential for immediate implementation of such authority without further testing and development of appropriate evaluation criteria.

• Allowing Medicare to contract competitively with a broader array of entities could enable the program to benefit from increased efficiency and performance. However, this would require significant time and effort to implement effectively, including preparing clear statements of work and contractor selection criteria.
• Coordination between new contractors and existing claims administration activities would be crucial to ensure a smooth transition and avoid disruptions to program services. CMS would need to develop a strategic plan for incorporating functional contractors and managing their activities.
• Overall, removing the contracting limitations imposed at Medicare's inception could modernize the program, but change would not yield immediate results. Careful and deliberate implementation of any reforms would be necessary to promote better performance and accountability while avoiding disruptions to program operations.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) has focused on reducing the cost of support operations and associated infrastructure to free up funds for modernization without increasing overall defense budgets. The Defense Science Board (DSB) issued two reports in 1996 addressing outsourcing and other opportunities for substantially reducing DOD support services.

• The first DSB report concluded that DOD could realize savings of 30 to 40 percent of logistics costs and achieve broad improvements in service delivery and responsiveness by outsourcing support services. The second DSB report provided a new vision where DOD would only provide warfighting, direct battlefield support, policy- and decision-making, and oversight activities, with all other activities done by the private sector.

• The DSB estimated that DOD could save about $30 billion annually by 2002, with $6 billion coming from CONUS logistics infrastructure activities. However, the Program Analysis and Evaluation (PA&E) directorate found that the DSB's savings estimates were overstated by about $4 billion.

• Our analysis confirms PA&E's conclusion that the DSB's logistics savings estimates are not well supported and are unlikely to be as large as estimated. We found that the Board's projected annual savings from reliability improvements are overstated, the 25-percent savings rate from outsourcing appears to be overly optimistic, and DSB assumed that DOD would overcome significant impediments to outsourcing all logistics functions.

• While DOD has achieved benefits from outsourcing, adequate competition has been key to achieving significant reductions. Our work has shown that competitive markets do not currently exist for some logistics activities, which may reduce the amount of savings that can be generated through outsourcing.

• Certain legal and cultural impediments must be overcome to fully implement DSB's recommendations, and these factors will mitigate portions of the projected savings. DOD has found that infrastructure reductions, whether through outsourcing or other means, are difficult and painful due to the need for up-front investments, installation closures, and job eliminations.

• We agree with DSB that there are many opportunities for significant reductions in logistics infrastructure costs, but the Board's projected savings are overly optimistic. Savings opportunities from consolidating and reengineering must be considered in addition to outsourcing.

<summary>
• Beginning in 1993, Congress and the administration agreed to cut federal employment levels as a means of reducing federal costs and controlling deficits. This led to the Federal Workforce Restructuring Act of 1994 and the National Performance Review, which mandated governmentwide reductions of 272,900 FTE positions through fiscal year 1999.
• Agencies took actions to maintain performance amid downsizing, including refocusing their missions, reengineering their work processes, and taking steps to build and maintain employee skills. For example, the Bureau of Reclamation shifted its focus from water project construction to water resources management, and the Office of Housing at HUD consolidated single family housing activities to reduce processing times.
• While officials and employees generally believed performance had been maintained, some expressed concerns about whether it could be sustained with additional downsizing. Limited performance measurement data showed that components generally met their own performance goals, but customer satisfaction was mixed, with some customers expressing dissatisfaction due to losses of staff with adequate technical expertise.

• The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) reduced its workforce by 1,894 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, with the Office of Housing accounting for the largest percentage of the downsizing. The Office of Housing took actions to refocus its mission, reengineer its work processes, and maintain employee skills, which helped it maintain performance during this period.
• The Department of the Interior (DOI) reduced its workforce by almost 10,200 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, with the Bureau of Reclamation (BOR) experiencing one of the largest percentage reductions. BOR refocused its mission, reengineered its work processes, and took steps to build and maintain employee skills, which helped it maintain performance amid downsizing.
• The General Services Administration (GSA) reduced its workforce by 4,535 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, with the Public Buildings Service (PBS) accounting for the largest percentage of the downsizing. PBS reengineered its work processes and took steps to build and maintain employee skills, which helped it maintain performance during this period.

• NASA reduced its workforce by nearly 4,000 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996,

<summary>
• The IRS designed the National Research Program (NRP) to obtain accurate information about taxpayers' compliance with tax laws and to use that information to improve audit selection and address compliance problems.
• The IRS has implemented several measures to ensure the quality of NRP data, including quality assurance reviews of the classification and audit processes, and data consistency checks.
• The NRP casebuilding and classification processes have helped minimize the burden on taxpayers with returns in the NRP sample, and the IRS plans to use NRP results to improve future iterations of the program.
• The IRS has consulted with outside stakeholders to enhance its efforts to minimize the burden on NRP-selected taxpayers and has made adjustments to the program based on its own testing and feedback.
• The IRS is on track for meeting its NRP goal of obtaining meaningful compliance data while minimizing the burden on taxpayers with returns in the NRP sample.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Census Bureau (Bureau) is responsible for planning the 2010 Census, including the American Community Survey (ACS) and the Master Address File/Topologically Integrated Geographic Encoding and Referencing (MAF/TIGER) enhancements. The Bureau has established an executive steering committee and several research and development planning groups to oversee these efforts.

* The Bureau has made progress in planning the 2010 Census, including involving experienced staff in the design process and recognizing the importance of strategic human capital management. However, the Bureau's plans still lack a comprehensive project plan, transparent budget information, and performance data from the 2000 Census.

* The Bureau's three-legged stool strategy, which includes ACS, MAF/TIGER, and a short-form-only census, is generally aligned with its goals for the 2010 Census. However, the successful implementation of this strategy faces significant challenges and risks.

* The Bureau's cost estimates for the 2010 Census continue an escalating trend, with the estimated cost of $11.3 billion making it the most expensive census in the nation's history. The Bureau's budget reporting does not fully capture the long-term fiscal exposure associated with the census.

* The Bureau's decision on how to use coverage measurement data in the 2010 Census appears to be premature, as the 2000 Census approach needs to be reworked. The Bureau should research procedures that could allow it to adjust census results for those purposes for which it is both legal and appropriate to do so.

* The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) ensure greater fiscal transparency for the 2010 Census, including updated life cycle cost estimates and an analysis of the sensitivity of these estimates to key assumptions.

* GAO also recommends that the Bureau improve the rigor of its planning process by developing a comprehensive project plan that consolidates budget, methodological, and other relevant information, and that the Bureau research the feasibility of procedures to adjust census results if necessary.
</summary>

<summary>
• The widespread use of health information technology, such as electronic prescribing, can improve the quality of care and reduce healthcare costs. Electronic prescribing allows healthcare providers to transmit prescriptions directly to pharmacies and access patient information like eligibility, formulary, benefits, and medication history.

• To transmit prescriptions electronically, multiple entities need access to an individual's protected health information (PHI). Federal laws and regulations dictate the acceptable use and disclosure of PHI, which includes treatment, payment, healthcare operations, and certain public health or research purposes.

• The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act establish standards to protect the privacy and security of PHI, including prescription drug use information. The HITECH Act strengthened these requirements and expanded enforcement provisions.

• The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has issued regulations, such as the HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules, to govern the use and disclosure of PHI. These rules establish methods for de-identifying PHI and require covered entities to implement reasonable safeguards to protect electronic PHI.

• The HITECH Act requires HHS to provide guidance on implementing HIPAA de-identification methods, but HHS has not yet issued this guidance due to competing priorities and internal reviews.

• HHS's Office for Civil Rights (OCR) has developed an enforcement process to investigate complaints and data breach notifications and require corrective actions from covered entities. OCR has also initiated a pilot audit program to assess covered entities' compliance with HIPAA regulations.

• However, OCR has not established plans for a sustained audit program or for auditing business associates, which is important because over 20% of data breaches have involved business associates.

• Without issuing the required de-identification guidance and establishing a sustained audit program, OCR has limited assurance that covered entities and business associates are properly safeguarding PHI, including Medicare beneficiaries' prescription drug use information.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Military Health Services System (MHSS) spends over $15 billion a year to provide medical support to active-duty military personnel and maintain the health of the active-duty force during peacetime. The MHSS has more than enough psychiatrists and clinical psychologists to meet its current and upcoming medical readiness requirements.
• The Psychopharmacology Demonstration Project (PDP) was established to train military clinical psychologists to prescribe psychotropic medication. However, the PDP faced several implementation problems, including a lack of clearly defined purpose, difficulty recruiting participants, and unresolved issues regarding supervision.
• The cost of the PDP was substantial, estimated at $6.1 million through the completion of the proctored year for those currently in the program, or about $610,000 per psychologist who completed the program. The cost-effectiveness of the PDP is unclear, as the MHSS has no current or upcoming need for psychologists who can prescribe medication.
• The PDP increased the number of MHSS mental health care providers who can prescribe drugs, which may reduce psychiatrists' workloads in some cases. However, psychiatrists, psychologists, and primary care physicians have different opinions on the effect of allowing psychologists to prescribe drugs on the quality of mental health care and collaboration among these providers.
• The MHSS has more than enough psychiatrists and clinical psychologists to meet its medical readiness requirements, and the cost of the PDP was substantial. Given the MHSS's readiness requirements and the PDP's persistent implementation difficulties, there is no reason to reinstate this demonstration project.
• If prescribing psychologists are needed in the future to meet DOD's medical readiness requirements, the Congress should require DOD to clearly demonstrate the need, define the role and scope of practice for prescribing psychologists, design an appropriate curriculum, and determine the level of supervision required.
• The PDP's implementation faced several problems, including a lack of clearly defined purpose, difficulty recruiting participants, and unresolved issues regarding supervision. These problems persisted throughout the project's duration.
• The cost-effectiveness of the PDP is unclear, and the MHSS has no current or upcoming need for psychologists who can prescribe medication. Given the MHSS's readiness requirements and the PDP's substantial

<summary>
* The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) project has made progress in building, integrating, and testing significant portions of the telescope, but resolving technical challenges in a timely manner and ensuring the OTIS test goes smoothly are key to continued progress within the project's schedule commitment.
* The project's ability to meet its future cost commitments is primarily challenged by the need to reduce the size of the prime contractor's workforce and control costs within the fiscal year 2016 budget.
</summary>

<summary>
• Experts agree that chemical facilities are among the most attractive targets for terrorists, but no one has yet comprehensively assessed security at these facilities.
• The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is developing a plan to protect the chemical sector, focusing on identifying high-priority facilities and developing a risk assessment methodology.
• Despite industry efforts to improve security, the extent of security preparedness at U.S. chemical facilities remains largely unknown, as DHS lacks the authority to require the industry to take actions to improve their security.
• Legislation has been proposed to grant DHS the authority to require high-risk chemical facilities to conduct vulnerability assessments and implement security measures, and to consider the use of inherently safer technologies.
</summary>

<summary>
• The major requirements for the protection of personal privacy by federal agencies are specified in the Privacy Act of 1974, the E-Government Act of 2002, and the Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002.
• The E-Government Act of 2002 requires agencies to conduct privacy impact assessments (PIAs) to identify and mitigate privacy risks in their information systems and collections.
• The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has faced challenges in ensuring that privacy concerns are addressed early and consistently reflected in its programs and guidance on emerging technologies.
• The development of guidelines for the information sharing environment has included efforts to address privacy considerations, but more specific implementation guidance is needed to ensure consistent protection of privacy across DHS and other participating agencies.
</summary>

<summary>
• Social Security is one of the largest federal programs in the United States, providing benefits to over 49 million beneficiaries, including retirees, disabled workers, and dependents.
• The Social Security program faces solvency challenges due to the retirement of the baby boomers, increases in life expectancy, and decreases in the fertility rate, which may require reductions in benefits, increases in revenues, or a combination of both to restore long-term solvency.
• The report analyzes the effects of various reform elements on the benefits of disabled workers and dependents, and explores options to protect these vulnerable populations from potential benefit reductions.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) was enacted in 2008 to address the severe financial crisis that rippled through the global economy. TARP established various programs to provide support to financial institutions, automakers, and the housing market.
• Many of the TARP programs have ended or are winding down, with Treasury recovering more funds than originally disbursed in some cases. However, Treasury continues to hold investments in some programs and the housing assistance programs remain active.
• The largest TARP program, the Capital Purchase Program, has seen repayments and income exceed the original amount disbursed. The Community Development Capital Initiative and the Automotive Industry Financing Program are also being wound down, with Treasury recovering a significant portion of its investments.

• The Making Home Affordable (MHA) program, including the Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP), has provided assistance to struggling homeowners, but participation has declined in recent years. Treasury has taken steps to extend and enhance the program to reach more borrowers.
• The Hardest Hit Fund and the FHA Short Refinance program have also provided assistance to homeowners, with varying levels of progress in disbursing funds and meeting participation goals across the states.
• Overall, Treasury continues to wind down the TARP programs, balancing the goals of protecting taxpayer investments, maximizing returns, and promoting financial stability. The housing assistance programs are expected to continue disbursing funds for several more years.
</summary>

<summary>
* The electricity sector in the United States is undergoing a significant transition as power companies face decisions on the future of coal-fueled electricity generating units in light of new regulations and changes in the market, such as recent low prices for natural gas. Power companies have already identified retirements of coal-fueled generating units beyond the range of estimates reported in 2012.
* The Department of Energy, Environmental Protection Agency, and Federal Energy Regulatory Commission have taken initial steps to implement a recommendation to establish a joint process to monitor industry's progress in responding to the four EPA regulations and other factors. However, stakeholders continue to express concerns about reliability and electricity prices, and proposed regulations focused on reducing emissions of carbon dioxide from the electricity sector may pose additional challenges for coal-fueled generating units.
* The initial coordination efforts across the three agencies are an important tool for understanding and monitoring the potential effects of EPA regulations and other factors on the electricity sector. Careful monitoring and coordination by the federal agencies incorporating the views of other stakeholders such as Regional Transmission Organizations will be even more important over the next several years as key regulations are finalized and implemented.
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) found that the Farm Service Agency (FSA) does not consistently determine the eligibility of estates kept open for more than 2 years, as required by regulations. This lack of oversight means the FSA cannot ensure that payments to these estates are proper.
• The GAO review found that the FSA did not conduct any eligibility determinations for 40% of the estates they reviewed, and some estates received over $500,000 in payments without any eligibility determinations. Even when determinations were made, the GAO found shortcomings, such as approving eligibility based on insufficient information.
• The GAO also found that the extent of eligibility determinations varied significantly across different states, suggesting inconsistent implementation of the rules. In one case, the GAO uncovered that a beneficiary was able to receive payments beyond the three-entity rule, which the FSA was unaware of until the GAO brought it to their attention.
• The GAO found that the FSA paid $1.1 billion in farm program payments to 172,801 deceased individuals from 1999 to 2005, with 40% of those payments going to individuals who had been dead for 3 or more years. The GAO provided specific examples of improper payments to deceased individuals.
• The GAO found that payments to deceased individuals through entities accounted for 58% of the $1.1 billion in total payments to deceased individuals, even though payments to all individuals through entities only accounted for 27% of total farm program payments.
• The GAO found that complex farming entities, particularly corporations and general partnerships, increase the potential for improper payments to deceased individuals, as the FSA relies on self-certification and lacks management controls to verify the accuracy of the information provided.
• The GAO recommended that the USDA conduct all required annual estate eligibility determinations, implement management controls to verify that individuals receiving payments have not died, and determine and recover any improper payments made to deceased individuals or entities that failed to disclose a member's death.
• The USDA agreed with the GAO's recommendations and has begun taking steps to address the issues identified in the report.
</summary>

<summary>
* The FAA's air traffic control (ATC) system must operate continuously to manage the flow of air traffic. The FAA's modernization program has experienced substantial cost overruns, schedule delays, and performance shortfalls over the past 16 years.
* The FAA lacks a complete and enforced systems architecture, reliable cost information, mature software acquisition processes, and an organizational culture that does not always act in the agency's long-term best interest. The FAA has begun to implement recommendations to address these issues, but more work is needed.
* The FAA's modernization program is being revised to focus on providing near-term user benefits, while continuing to address critical time-driven activities and replace aging infrastructure. The FAA will need to establish baselines and performance measurements to track progress under the revised approach.
* The FAA faces a significant challenge in ensuring its systems are ready for the year 2000 date change, as delays in completing critical awareness and assessment activities have left little time for the remaining renovation, validation, and implementation activities.
* The FAA has implemented its Acquisition Management System (AMS) to improve the acquisition of new technology, but the agency will need to use reliable and complete data to establish realistic baselines and have a comprehensive system of performance measurements.
* The FAA has an opportunity to regain user confidence by delivering systems that benefit them, but it must proceed cautiously to avoid repeating past practices of undue concern for schedules at the expense of disciplined systems development and careful, thorough testing.
</summary>

<summary>
• The United States funded rule of law programs and related activities in countries throughout the world during fiscal years 1993-98, totaling at least $970 million.
• The total annual rule of law funding increased from $128 million to $218 million over the period.
• The Latin America and the Caribbean region received the largest share of funding, with about 36 percent.
• Africa, Central Europe, and the newly independent states of the former Soviet Union received about 15 percent each.
• Funding for Central Europe grew from about $9 million in fiscal year 1993 to over $67 million in fiscal year 1998, accounting for 31 percent of the worldwide rule of law assistance that year.
• Rule of law assistance in Latin America and the Caribbean declined from about $57 million (44 percent of the worldwide total) to $42 million (19 percent).
• Rule of law assistance to Africa also declined from $38 million (30 percent of the worldwide total) in 1993 to $29 million (13 percent) in 1998.
• The decline in funding for Latin America and the Caribbean and Africa was primarily due to the shift in funding to other regions, mainly Central Europe.
• The decline in funding for fiscal year 1996 may be largely explained by problems with USAID's automated information system.
• The source document provides detailed data on the trends in rule of law funding during fiscal years 1993-98.
</summary>

<summary>
• Franchise funds are government-run, self-supporting businesslike enterprises that provide a variety of common administrative services to federal agencies. They are required to recover their full costs of doing business and are allowed to retain up to 4 percent of their total annual income.
• The Government Management Reform Act of 1994 authorized the establishment of the franchise fund pilot program, with the expectation that the funds would be able to provide common administrative services more efficiently than federal agencies' own personnel.
• The original operating principles for franchise funds included offering services on a fully competitive basis, using a comprehensive set of performance measures to assess the quality of services, and establishing cost and performance benchmarks against their competitors.
• However, the review found that the franchise funds did not always adhere to competitive procedures, ensure fair and reasonable prices, or provide adequate oversight of contractor performance, which raises concerns about whether they are delivering good value to the government.
</summary>

<summary>
• Wildland fires play an important ecological role, but various land use and management practices have reduced the normal frequency of fires in many ecosystems. This, combined with more homes and communities built in fire-prone areas, has increased the risk to lives, health, property, and infrastructure.
• Federal agencies and nonfederal entities collaborate in various ways to reduce wildland fire risk, including fuel reduction, fire preparedness, prevention, and education activities. The Cohesive Strategy provides a framework for this collaboration, emphasizing coordination across jurisdictions and setting national goals for mitigating fire risk.
• Factors that enhance federal-nonfederal collaboration include federal authorities that enable cross-jurisdictional work, landscape-scale restoration efforts, joint planning, engaged leadership, and community engagement. Factors that hinder collaboration include environmental regulations, limited agency resources, and community resistance to risk-reducing actions.
• To improve their ability to reduce wildland fire risk, federal officials and stakeholders suggested enhancing implementation of the Cohesive Strategy, increasing collaborative planning, expanding education, increasing prevention efforts, improving timber-processing capability, and encouraging state and local adoption of risk-reducing laws and ordinances.
• The Forest Service and Interior have performance measures to assess their individual wildland fire management efforts, but the Wildland Fire Leadership Council has not developed measures to assess national progress toward achieving the Cohesive Strategy's goals, as called for in the strategy.
• We recommend that the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior direct the Forest Service and the Office of Wildland Fire, respectively, to work with the Wildland Fire Leadership Council to develop measures to assess national progress toward achieving the Cohesive Strategy's goals.
• The Departments of Agriculture and the Interior provided comments on the report, with Interior disagreeing with the recommendation, citing concerns about the burden of additional measures and the ability to control nonfederal partner participation.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Battle of Normandy Foundation, a private nonprofit organization, received $3 million in surcharge coin proceeds from the U.S. Treasury to create and dedicate a United States D-Day and Battle of Normandy Memorial in Normandy, France. However, the Foundation has experienced significant financial and internal control problems, and its liabilities substantially exceed its assets, casting doubt on its ability to continue operations.
• The GAO audit found that the Foundation's spending on program activities was within industry standards, its promotion of tours to Normandy was appropriate, and the adjustments made to the Foundation's records regarding rent owed by the former president's company were reasonable and approved by the Board.
</summary>

<summary>
* Millions of current and future retirees rely on private or public defined benefit (DB) pension plans. The financial condition of these plans depends on adequate contributions and prudent investments.
* Private sector pension plan investment decisions must comply with the provisions of ERISA, which stipulates fiduciary standards based on the principle of a prudent man standard.
* Public sector DB plans are not subject to funding, vesting and most other requirements applicable to private sector DB plans under ERISA, but must follow requirements established for them under applicable state law.
* Hedge funds are privately organized and administered by professional managers and often engage in active trading of various types of securities, commodity futures, options contracts, and other investment vehicles.
* Private equity funds are privately managed pools of capital that invest in companies, many of which are not listed on a stock exchange, and seek to obtain financial returns through long-term appreciation based on corporate stewardship, improved operating processes and financial restructuring.
* Pension plans typically invest in private equity through limited partnerships in which the general partner develops an investment strategy and limited partners provide the large majority of the capital.
* While the majority of plans with investments in hedge funds or private equity have small allocations to these assets, a few plans have relatively large allocations.
* Pension plan investment in hedge funds has experienced greater growth in recent years compared to investment in private equity, which increased markedly following a 1979 Labor clarification that plans may make some investments in riskier assets.
* Larger plans, measured by total plan assets, are more likely to invest in hedge funds and private equity compared to mid-size plans, and the extent to which small plans invest in these assets is unknown.
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. territories of American Samoa, CNMI, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands have some discretion in setting Medicaid and CHIP eligibility standards, provider payment rates, and covered benefits. However, they face significant differences in Medicaid and CHIP funding compared to the states.

• The territories' Medicaid programs are required to cover certain mandatory benefits, but some territories do not cover all mandatory benefits due to limited funding and infrastructure. The territories also vary in the optional benefits they choose to cover.

• Temporary increases in federal Medicaid and CHIP funding, such as under the Affordable Care Act, have enabled the territories to increase spending and avoid funding shortfalls. However, the territories may experience funding shortfalls in the future as this temporary funding is exhausted.

• The territories have limited program integrity efforts, with the exception of Puerto Rico, which has a program integrity unit. None of the territories have established Medicaid Fraud Control Units, as required, or obtained exemptions from this requirement.

• The territories' incomplete service-level expenditure reporting on the CMS-64 form hinders program integrity efforts, as it makes it difficult to identify potential fraud, waste, and abuse.

• CMS has conducted comprehensive program integrity reviews only in Puerto Rico and has not done so in the other territories, citing their smaller Medicaid expenditures. This limited federal oversight provides little assurance that Medicaid is protected from fraud, waste, and abuse in the territories.

• Single audits conducted by independent auditors have identified various internal control and compliance deficiencies in the territories' Medicaid programs, but CMS has faced challenges in working with the territories to resolve these issues due to their limited resources.

• To enhance Medicaid program integrity in the territories, GAO recommends that CMS reexamine its program integrity strategy and develop a cost-effective approach, which could include establishing oversight mechanisms, assisting territories in improving their spending information, and conducting additional program assessments.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program to clean up highly contaminated hazardous waste sites. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) administers the program, oversees cleanups performed by responsible parties, and performs cleanups itself.
• The report found that 1,789 sites are potentially eligible for the National Priorities List (NPL), which represents EPA's highest priorities for cleanup. However, the report recommends that EPA and states take timely action to assess the risks of these sites, set cleanup priorities, and determine cleanup responsibilities to address the risks posed by many of these sites.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of State faces challenges in managing its visa workload and maintaining its goal of keeping interview wait times under 30 days at all posts due to increasing visa demand and security requirements.
• The report recommends that the Department of State develop a long-term strategy to address the projected increase in visa demand, improve the reliability of visa wait time data, and identify and share best practices among consular posts to manage workload and reduce wait times.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is responsible for managing the federal government's civilian workforce, including the retirement program for federal employees.
• OPM has faced significant challenges in modernizing its retirement processing system, including failed initiatives and the termination of a major contract.
• OPM has only partially implemented two of the eight capabilities it planned to achieve through its retirement modernization efforts, with the remaining six capabilities not yet implemented.
• OPM has not developed a complete plan for its restructured retirement modernization program, including defining the scope, implementation strategy, and performance measures.
• OPM has not developed a reliable cost estimate for the retirement modernization program, which is essential for effective program planning and oversight.
• OPM has not established a basis for reliable earned value management (EVM), which is critical for measuring and reporting program progress.
• OPM has weaknesses in its processes for developing and managing requirements for the retirement modernization program.
• OPM has not begun planning for testing activities early in the program's life cycle, which is a recognized best practice.
• OPM's oversight entities have been ineffective in ensuring the retirement modernization program is on track and taking corrective actions when needed.
</summary>

<summary>
* The number of school-aged children with limited English proficiency in the nation has grown dramatically, increasing from less than 1 million in 1980 to more than 3.5 million in 1998.
* The Bilingual Education Act (BEA) was passed in 1968 to educate students with limited English proficiency so that they can reach the academic standards expected of all students.
* The four bilingual education grant programs authorized by the BEA are Program Development and Implementation Grants, Program Enhancement Projects, Comprehensive School Grants, and Systemwide Improvement Grants.
* The effectiveness of the four bilingual education programs on a national level is unknown because locally collected data are not comparable.
* All four bilingual education programs share the same performance goals and measures, possess similar eligibility criteria, and allow similar uses of program funds.
* The Congress may want to consider consolidating the four bilingual education programs into one program to reduce overlap and inefficiencies.
* Consolidating the four bilingual education programs may provide benefits other than cost savings to the Department of Education, such as allowing staff to reallocate time to other important program-related activities.
* Consolidation may also directly benefit grantees applying to more than one of the bilingual education programs by reducing the burden associated with applying to multiple federal programs.
* The Department of Education has decided to support consolidating the four programs into one, which is consistent with the President's budget proposal.
* The Department of Education's review did not address whether the federal government or states should administer the consolidated program.
</summary>

<summary>
• The National Crime Information Center (NCIC) is a computerized criminal justice information system maintained by the FBI that serves as a repository of data on crimes and criminals of nationwide interest and as a locator file for missing and unidentified persons.
• The FBI's Criminal Justice Information Services (CJIS) Division is responsible for managing NCIC, and the CJIS Advisory Policy Board, with representatives from criminal justice and national security agencies, establishes policies for NCIC use.
• Local-level governance of NCIC use is performed by the Control Terminal Agency (CSA), which is responsible for auditing all law enforcement agencies (LEAs) that enter data into NCIC within their jurisdiction to ensure compliance with NCIC policies.

• CJIS conducts triennial audits of CSAs to assess their compliance with NCIC policies, including the requirement that LEAs enter reports of missing children into NCIC within 2 hours.
