* The Clean Energy Transmission and Reliability (CETR) program aims to improve energy system decision-making by fostering the development of system measurement, modeling, and risk analysis. The Smart Grid program focuses on modernizing the distribution portion of the electric delivery system, while the Cybersecurity for Energy Delivery Systems (CEDS) program aims to strengthen the energy infrastructure against cyber threats.
* The Energy Storage program develops and demonstrates new and advanced energy storage technologies to enable the stability, resiliency, and reliability of the future electric grid. The Transformer Resilience and Advanced Components (TRAC) program supports modernization and resilience of the grid by addressing the unique challenges facing transformers and other critical components.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) of 1986 was enacted to guide the process for creating memorials in the District of Columbia. It established criteria for the placement and design of commemorative works, as well as the roles of various government agencies in the process.
* The CWA divides the District of Columbia into three areas with different requirements for memorial placement, with the "Reserve" area being a no-build zone to preserve the integrity of the National Mall. Sponsors of commemorative works must obtain congressional authorization and approval from various agencies before construction can begin.
* Since the CWA's enactment, Congress has authorized 33 memorials, with 18 completed, 11 in progress, and 4 having lapsed authorizations. The process involves multiple steps, including site selection, design approval, fundraising, and construction, with oversight from entities such as the National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission and the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Senate Finance Committee approved the America's Healthy Future Act of 2009, which includes provisions to reform the private health insurance market. The bill would require individuals to maintain health insurance and impose penalties for noncompliance.
* The bill would establish new federal standards for private health insurance plans, including prohibiting exclusions for pre-existing conditions and requiring guaranteed issue and renewal. It would also create health insurance exchanges where individuals and small businesses could purchase coverage.
* The bill would provide subsidies to help certain individuals purchase health insurance through the exchanges. It would also establish a program for states to offer a basic health plan for low-income individuals not eligible for Medicaid.
* The bill would create incentives for the establishment of non-profit health insurance cooperatives through a $6 billion funding program. It would also include provisions related to abortion coverage in qualified health plans.
* The bill would impose an excise tax on high-cost employer-sponsored health insurance plans and an annual fee on health insurance providers to help pay for the expanded coverage.
* The bill would also limit the deductibility of executive compensation for health insurers and require employers to coordinate the subsidy and deduction for retiree prescription drug coverage.
* The bill would modify tax-advantaged accounts, such as flexible spending accounts and health savings accounts, by limiting contributions and increasing penalties for non-qualified distributions.
* The bill would also increase the threshold for the medical expense itemized deduction from 7.5% to 10% of adjusted gross income for taxpayers under age 65.
</summary>

<summary>
* High risk health insurance pools are programs established by 35 states to provide coverage to individuals who cannot obtain or afford health insurance in the private market, primarily due to pre-existing health conditions. These pools are designed to fill a niche in the health insurance system and serve as a safety net for the non-group market.

* High risk pools are generally small and underfunded, with premiums and cost-sharing requirements often making the coverage unaffordable. They also typically exclude coverage for pre-existing conditions for 6-12 months. As a result, some researchers are skeptical that high risk pools can substantially reduce the number of uninsured.

* The federal government has provided financial assistance to state high risk pools through grant programs, including seed grants to establish new pools and operational grants to defray losses. These grants have been authorized and appropriated by Congress on several occasions since the 1990s.

* The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) requires the establishment of a temporary high risk pool program prior to 2014 to provide coverage to individuals with pre-existing conditions who have been uninsured for at least 6 months. The majority of states have opted to run their own high risk pools under this program.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) was created in 1951 to meet the nation's airlift needs in times of crisis, and it has been formally activated on two separate occasions over the program's 57-year history.
* The CRAF program provides benefits to both the Department of Defense (DOD) and the U.S. airline industry, but potential changes in DOD's strategic airlift requirements and air mobility force structure may affect the CRAF program.
* Recent legislation, including the FY2008 National Defense Authorization Act, has addressed various aspects of the CRAF program, including a comprehensive assessment and a study on the size and mix of the airlift force.
</summary>

<summary>
• The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency within the U.S. Department of Commerce that serves as the executive branch's principal advisory office on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies. It represents the executive branch in both domestic and international telecommunications and information policy activities, including international negotiations regarding global agreements on spectrum management and domestic use of spectrum resources by federal agencies.

• The NTIA administers various grant programs, including the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program. It also plays a lead role in the Department of Commerce's Internet Policy Task Force and collaborates with other federal agencies, such as the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), on various initiatives.

• The NTIA is responsible for managing spectrum used by federal agencies and works in consultation with the FCC on matters concerning spectrum access, technology, and policy. It also leads and participates in interagency efforts to develop Internet policy and represents American interests in international spectrum-related negotiations.

• The NTIA's Office of Spectrum Management (OSM) formulates and establishes plans and policies to ensure the effective, efficient, and equitable use of the spectrum both nationally and internationally. The Office of Policy Analysis and Development (OPAD) supports the NTIA's role as the principal adviser to the Executive Branch on telecommunications and information policies.

• The NTIA's Office of International Affairs (OIA) develops and implements policies to enhance U.S. companies' ability to compete globally in the information technology and communications (ICT) sectors. The Institute for Telecommunication Sciences (ITS) provides technical support to the NTIA and conducts research and engineering to promote more efficient and effective use of the radio spectrum.

• The NTIA has been tasked with various responsibilities under the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012, including establishing requirements for a $135 million grant program to help states plan for participation in a new, nationwide public safety broadband network and supporting the First Responder Network Authority (FirstNet) in planning, building, and managing the network.

• The NTIA is required to work with the FCC to identify specific bands of spectrum for auction and to collect auction proceeds, which are to be deposited into the Public Safety Trust Fun

<summary>
• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 was the first omnibus energy legislation enacted in more than a decade. It aimed to improve the reliability of the U.S. bulk power system by clarifying FERC's authority to establish and regulate an electric reliability organization (ERO).
• The Act required FERC to promulgate rules to create a FERC-certified ERO, which would develop and enforce reliability standards for the bulk power system, including cybersecurity protection. The ERO can impose penalties on entities that violate FERC-approved reliability standards.
• The Act also gave FERC the authority to designate geographic areas as being congested and issue construction permits for interstate electric transmission facilities under certain conditions. It also allowed the Western Area Power Administration and Southwestern Power Administration to participate with other entities in the design, development, construction, operation, maintenance, or ownership of transmission facilities.

• The Act amended the Federal Power Act to clarify that a load-serving entity is entitled to use its transmission facilities or firm transmission rights to serve its existing customers before it is obligated to make its transmission capacity available for other uses.
• The Act required state regulatory authorities to consider implementing net metering and smart metering standards within a certain timeframe. It also repealed the mandatory purchase requirement under Section 210 of PURPA for new contracts if FERC finds that a competitive electricity market exists.
• The Act repealed the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA), which had set forth the structure of holding companies and provided for SEC regulation of mergers and diversification proposals. The Act gave FERC and state commissions access to the books and records of holding companies and their affiliates.
• The Act directed FERC to facilitate price transparency in wholesale electric markets and prohibited any entity from willingly and knowingly reporting false information to a federal agency relating to the price of electricity sold at wholesale or the availability of transmission capacity.
• The Act increased criminal and civil penalties for violations of the Federal Power Act and gave FERC refund authority over voluntary short-term sales of electricity by certain entities, including power marketing administrations and the Tennessee Valley Authority.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) was enacted in 1936 to help small businesses compete with larger rivals, particularly in the grocery industry. The act prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality."
* The Department of Justice has been less than enthusiastic about the act, believing it is not beneficial to consumers. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has acted inconsistently with respect to R-P actions, with most cases brought by disfavored buyers.
* Affirmative defenses to R-P violations include commodities not of "like grade and quality," sales for export, "meeting competition," and "cost justified" price differentials. The 1938 Nonprofit Institutions Act also created a broad exemption from the general price-discrimination prohibition.
* The Supreme Court has provided significant interpretations of the scope of the nonprofit exemption, ruling that not all purchases by nonprofit hospitals are exempt and that government purchases for retail competition are subject to R-P.

* Health maintenance organizations (HMOs) have been found to be "eligible institutions" under the Nonprofit Institutions Act, with the court relying on the "basic institutional function" of HMOs to provide a "complete panoply" of health-care services.
* If none of the affirmative defenses apply and the non-profit exemption is unavailable, price discrimination in violation of the R-P Act is proved. However, the successful plaintiff is not automatically entitled to damages.
* In the mid-1970s, Congress considered proposals to amend or repeal the R-P Act, but no legislation was introduced at that time, and none has been introduced since.
* The Antitrust Modernization Commission recommended that Congress repeal the R-P Act in its entirety, noting that it has had the unintended effect of limiting discounting and causing consumers to pay higher prices.
* Whether the current economic climate will result in further efforts to modify or repeal the R-P Act is unknown at this time.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Take Care Clause of the Constitution imposes a duty on the President to faithfully execute the law, but also grants the President discretion in how to enforce the law.
* Courts generally do not review prosecutorial discretion in criminal matters or administrative enforcement discretion, deferring to the executive branch's expertise.
* Congress can limit executive enforcement discretion by providing clear statutory guidelines or mandates, but cannot directly enforce federal law or compel the executive to prosecute specific individuals.
* The Supreme Court's decision in Morrison v. Olson suggests Congress can restrict executive enforcement discretion as long as it does not prevent the executive from accomplishing its constitutional functions.
* Courts have upheld the qui tam provision of the False Claims Act, which allows private parties to initiate civil enforcement actions, as not impermissibly interfering with executive enforcement discretion.
* Congress can prohibit or require the consideration of certain factors in enforcement decisions and set enforcement priorities, which courts can then review for compliance.
* The extent to which Congress can remove executive enforcement discretion entirely, especially in the criminal context, remains an open question.
</summary>

<summary>
* The official U.S. poverty rate in 2013 was 14.5%, down from 15.0% in 2012, marking the first statistically significant drop since 2006. Poverty tends to rise when the economy is faltering and fall when the economy is in sustained growth, as evidenced by the increases during the two recent recessions.
* The Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) provides a more comprehensive assessment of poverty by including in-kind benefits, tax credits, and necessary expenses such as taxes, work-related expenses, and medical costs. The SPM paints a different picture of poverty, with higher rates among the elderly and lower rates among children compared to the official measure.
* The SPM highlights the importance of work supports and in-kind benefits in reducing poverty, especially for families with children. It also underscores the vulnerability of the elderly to medical expenses, which can significantly impact their ability to meet basic needs.
</summary>

<summary>
* The United States is subject to a spending limit of $19.1 billion in amber box outlays under the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Agreement on Agriculture (AoA). The AoA categorizes agricultural domestic support programs into three groups: green box (minimally or non-trade distorting), blue box (production-limiting), and amber box (most market-distorting).
* The United States notified $127.5 billion in green box outlays, including spending on general services, domestic food aid, decoupled income support, payments for relief from natural disasters, structural adjustment through investment aids, and environmental payments. The United States also utilized $5.3 billion in de minimis exclusions and reported $6.9 billion in amber box policies.
* The United States has never exceeded its AoA limit, with the closest approach being in 2000 when it notified a total AMS of $16.8 billion. However, U.S. domestic farm policies are also subject to the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM), which evaluates the market distortion of a program or policy in terms of its measurable market effects on international trade and prices.
</summary>

<summary>
• The campus-based student financial aid programs, which include the Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG), the Federal Work-Study (FWS), and the Federal Perkins Loan programs, are unique in that the mix and amount of aid awarded to students are determined by the institutions rather than according to non-discretionary award criteria. These programs have been in existence for decades, but their authorizations have expired, and their future is uncertain as Congress considers reauthorization of the Higher Education Act.

• The campus-based programs serve a relatively small proportion of students compared to other federal aid programs, and the formula for allocating funds to institutions has been criticized for favoring long-term participants and not adequately targeting low-income students. Proposals have been made to eliminate or consolidate the campus-based programs to simplify the federal aid system, but proponents argue that the programs provide unique benefits, such as institutional matching and discretion in awarding aid.

• As the Perkins Loan program winds down, issues related to the distribution of loan assets and the loss of additional borrowing capacity for students may be considered during reauthorization. Congress may also consider proposals to extend the Perkins Loan program or incorporate its features into other federal student loan programs.
</summary>

<summary>
* Adults may go missing for various reasons, including personal choice, disabling conditions, natural disasters, or crimes.
* State alert systems for missing vulnerable adults have been implemented in at least 11 states, often modeled after the AMBER Alert system for missing children.
* These state alert systems target individuals with cognitive, mental, or physical impairments, with varying criteria for activating the alerts.
* Administration of the alert systems is a cooperative effort between state and local law enforcement agencies, with some states having a lead state agency responsible for activating the alerts.
* States have mechanisms in place for coordinating alerts with other states when a missing individual is believed to have crossed state lines.
* Costs for operating the alert systems range from around $40,000 to $182,000 annually, with some states absorbing the costs within existing budgets.
* Most states have used their alert systems, with the number of alerts activated ranging from 1 to 82, and the majority of missing individuals being found alive.
* Congress is considering a federal role in assisting states with developing and coordinating these alert systems for missing vulnerable adults.
</summary>

<summary>
• The report describes and analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2017, including the enacted FY2016 appropriations, the Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, the Trump Administration's requests for additional funding, and the appropriations measures developed in response.
• The report discusses the implementation of the Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) for DHS, which was introduced in FY2017 and reorganized the department's appropriations into four categories: Operations and Support; Procurement, Construction and Improvement; Research and Development; and Federal Assistance. The report also provides detailed comparisons of the FY2016 enacted and FY2017 requested and enacted appropriations for various DHS components and titles.
• The report also discusses the Budget Control Act, which established discretionary spending caps and allowed for adjustments to those caps for certain types of spending, such as emergency spending, overseas contingency operations, and disaster relief. The report explains how these adjustments were used in the FY2017 DHS appropriations process.
</summary>

<summary>
* The September 11, 2001 attacks drew attention to the security of the nation's water supply and water quality infrastructure, which have long been recognized as potentially vulnerable to terrorist attacks. These systems include surface and ground water sources, dams, reservoirs, treatment facilities, and distribution systems, and are owned and managed by both public and private entities.
* After 9/11, federal agencies such as the Bureau of Reclamation and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers implemented security measures at their facilities, while local utilities conducted vulnerability assessments and made security improvements. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has taken various organizational and planning steps to strengthen water security, including developing guidance and tools for utilities.
* Congress has provided appropriations to federal agencies for security-related programs and activities, and has considered legislation to address issues such as physical security, communication and coordination, and research. Debates have also occurred over the roles of different federal agencies, such as EPA and the Department of Homeland Security, in regulating water sector security.
* Ongoing challenges include the distributed and diverse ownership of water infrastructure, the need for coordination and information sharing among various stakeholders, and the costs of implementing additional security measures. Policymakers continue to grapple with these issues to ensure the protection of the nation's critical water infrastructure.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV) reauthorized and amended the Perkins Act, which provides federal support for career and technical education. Perkins IV retains the overall purpose of the act, making only technical changes.

* Perkins IV modifies the state allotment formula, requiring states to distribute at least 85% of state grant funds to the local level and allowing states to reserve up to 10% for rural areas and high percentages of career and technical education students.

* Perkins IV strengthens accountability requirements, specifying separate core indicators of performance for the secondary and postsecondary levels and linking the secondary indicators to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA).

* Perkins IV requires eligible agencies and recipients to establish adjusted levels of performance for each core indicator and imposes sanctions for failing to meet at least 90% of these levels.

* Perkins IV retains the tech-prep program as a separate program, but allows eligible agencies to combine their tech-prep funds with their state grant funds, and expands the contents of tech-prep programs.
</summary>

<summary>
* The report explains the major provisions of the federal estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes as they apply to transfers in 2014. It discusses the gross estate, deductions from the gross estate, computation of the tax, including allowable tax credits, the federal gift tax, and the generation-skipping transfer tax.
* The report also discusses the purpose of the generation-skipping transfer tax, the different types of generation-skipping transfers, and the calculation of the tax, including the applicable rate, exemptions, and exclusions. The liability for the tax is determined by the type of transfer.
</summary>

<summary>
• Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a critical function in protecting the United States from terrorists and their instruments of destruction.
• The U.S. government has implemented various programs and policies to enhance border security, including pushing the border outwards, hardening the border, facilitating legitimate travel and trade, strengthening the border through intelligence, and engaging other actors.
• Key initiatives include pre-inspections at foreign airports, advance passenger and cargo manifests, the Container Security Initiative, and the Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism.
• The U.S. has also invested in border technology, such as biometric identifiers, smart containers, and integrated data systems, to harden the border.
• Facilitating legitimate travel and trade is achieved through programs like NEXUS, SENTRI, and the Free and Secure Trade (FAST) program.
• Intelligence plays a crucial role in border security, with the Terrorist Screening Database and the Automated Targeting System being key tools.
</summary>

<summary>
• Cabo Verde is a small island nation off the coast of West Africa with historical ties to the United States. It is considered a success story in Africa, with a stable democracy, high per capita income, and positive social indicators.
• Cabo Verde's strategic location has made it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe and a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic. U.S.-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects.
• Cabo Verde transitioned to democracy in 1991 and has since had a consensus-based political system dominated by two main parties. The current government, led by the MPD party, has prioritized economic expansion, job growth, and infrastructure development.

• Cabo Verde faces some rule of law and human rights challenges, but its record is better than most other African countries. It is classified as a lower-middle-income economy and ranks within the medium tier of human development.
• Cabo Verde's economy has been sluggish in recent years due to its dependence on Europe, but it has seen a recovery in 2016 and 2017 driven by tourism and foreign investment. Poverty has decreased, but remains a challenge.
• Cabo Verde has sought to diversify its aid and trade partnerships, strengthening ties with countries like China, Brazil, and Angola. It has also pursued deeper bilateral and investment ties with the United States and the European Union.

• Cabo Verde's main transnational security challenge is the threat of illicit narcotics transshipment through its territory. The United States provides assistance to Cabo Verde to counter this threat, including through an IMET program and occasional DOD support.
• Cabo Verde has received substantial U.S. development assistance through two Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) Compacts, which have focused on improving the investment climate, financial sector reforms, and water and sanitation infrastructure.
• While traditional sources of bilateral aid have fallen in recent years, Cabo Verde remains a minor U.S. trade partner, with limited exports to the United States under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA).
</summary>

<summary>
• The return of security cooperation between the United States and New Zealand has forged a new security partnership between the two countries. Several organizations and groups, including the United States-New Zealand Council and the Friends of New Zealand Congressional Caucus, help promote bilateral ties between the two nations.

• The Wellington Declaration of 2010 was a key turning point in United States-New Zealand relations, enabling a reorientation of the bilateral relationship and putting aside past differences. New Zealand's military commitment to Afghanistan and its participation in regional exercises like RIMPAC have positively affected perceptions in Washington and underlined the value of partnering with New Zealand.

• New Zealand's national security and defense interests are defined in the 2010 Defence White Paper, which highlights the importance of a rules-based international order, strong international linkages, and a sound global economy. New Zealand has set itself a goal of strengthening its leadership role in the South Pacific, which it has identified as an area of fragility.

• New Zealand's strategic geography views Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia as its "near abroad," and it has traditionally partnered with Australia in promoting shared security interests in the region. New Zealand's increasing Pacifika population and its national interests in the region have influenced its foreign policy towards the Asia Pacific.

• Beyond the South Pacific, New Zealand's relationship with the broader Asia Pacific has increased in importance, as alternative patterns of trade have shifted its economic focus towards Asia and the United States. New Zealand's economy has become increasingly linked to China, and the government promotes trade with China while being sensitive to anything that might disturb the nation's lucrative and growing trade relationship.

• There are a range of views in New Zealand on the rise of China, its implications for New Zealand, and the way New Zealand should position itself within the shifting geopolitical and trade dynamics of the region. Some see opportunities in China's engagement, while others are more concerned about the potential implications.

• China's aid to the Pacific, with its relative lack of transparency and focus on buildings and soft loans, differs in its approach from Western development assistance. China's increasing military capability will likely give it the ability to be more directly involved in the Pacific region in the future.

• Subtle differences in values can explain past differences in the U.S.-New Zealand relationship, and a more layered and nuanced understanding of these areas of commonality an

<summary>
* The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods for the President to appoint officers: with the advice and consent of the Senate, or during the Senate's recess. This has led to tension between the President and Congress.
* President Obama faced difficulties in obtaining Senate confirmation for nominees to lead the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (CFPB) and the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB). In response, he made recess appointments to these positions.
* The legality of these recess appointments has been challenged, raising questions about the scope of the President's recess appointment power and the impact on the appointees' statutory authorities.

* A reviewing court would first consider issues of justiciability, such as whether the plaintiffs have standing and whether the claims present nonjusticiable political questions.
* Private plaintiffs impacted by actions taken by the CFPB or NLRB after the recess appointments may have standing to challenge the appointments.
* Congressional plaintiffs, such as individual members or the Senate as an institution, would face a more rigorous standing inquiry due to the separation of powers issues involved.

* The political question doctrine may prevent a court from reaching the merits of a challenge, particularly regarding the length of a recess necessary to trigger the President's recess appointment power.
* The Constitution does not define "Recess of the Senate" for purposes of the Recess Appointments Clause, leading to ambiguity about the minimum length of a recess required.
* Linking the Recess Appointments Clause to the Adjournment Clause could suggest a minimum recess duration of more than three days, but a court may be hesitant to establish a bright-line rule without a clear constitutional basis.

* The scope of the CFPB Director's authority under the recess appointment may depend on the interpretation of the Consumer Financial Protection Act's provisions regarding the Secretary of the Treasury's interim authority.
* One interpretation would allow the recess appointed Director to exercise the full powers of the office, while another would restrict the Director to only the Bureau's newly established powers, with the Secretary retaining authority over the transferred powers.
* The latter interpretation may raise separation of powers concerns by indirectly limiting the President's recess appointment power, though the extent of the infringement is unclear and could depend on the analytical framework applied by the court.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) provides for the expedited removal of certain arriving aliens who do not have valid entry documents or have attempted to gain admission through fraud or misrepresentation.
* Expedited removal was initially limited to arriving aliens, but the government has gradually expanded its use to cover aliens who entered the United States by sea within the last two years and aliens found within 100 miles of the border within 14 days of entry.
* Aliens subject to expedited removal are generally not entitled to a hearing or further review, but they may seek administrative review of a credible fear claim or a claim that they are a U.S. citizen, lawful permanent resident, refugee, or asylee.
* The expedited removal process has faced legal challenges, but courts have largely dismissed such challenges for lack of jurisdiction or rejected them on substantive grounds.
* The government has the statutory authority to further expand the use of expedited removal, but doing so could raise constitutional concerns regarding the due process rights of aliens already present in the United States.
</summary>

<summary>
* The legal framework for congressional redistricting involves constitutional and federal statutory requirements, as well as case law interpretations, which have significantly shaped how congressional districts are drawn.
* Pending Supreme Court cases could continue to impact the process of congressional redistricting and the degree to which challenges to redistricting plans will be successful.
</summary>

<summary>
• The federal government has increased funding for wildfire protection programs in response to severe fire seasons in the past decade. This includes the National Fire Plan proposed by President Clinton in 2000 and the Healthy Forests Initiative proposed by President Bush in 2002.
• Federal wildfire appropriations have increased substantially, from an average of $1.1 billion for 1994-1999 to an average of $3.4 billion for 2004-2009. This has led to concerns about the high costs of wildfire management and its effect on other aspects of federal land management.
• Fuel reduction efforts have been proposed as a means of reducing wildfire suppression costs, but the acreage treated has not kept pace with the lands at high or moderate risk of significant ecological damage from wildfire due to high fuel loads.
• The Federal Land Assistance, Management, and Enhancement (FLAME) Act was enacted in 2010 to establish separate FLAME Wildfire Suppression Reserve Funds for the Forest Service and Department of Interior to insulate federal land and resource management programs from the financial impacts of borrowing to pay for wildfire suppression efforts.
• The states are responsible for protecting non-federal lands from wildfires, but the federal government provides cooperative fire assistance to states through the Forest Service. This assistance has increased substantially since 2001.
• Concerns have been raised about the appropriate federal role in protecting structures and communities, as well as providing assistance for post-fire rehabilitation of private lands and resources.
• Legislation has been introduced to address post-fire rehabilitation, including expedited processes for recovery and financial assistance, but no legislation has been enacted.
• The Collaborative Forest Landscape Restoration Act, enacted in 2009, provides a collaborative process for long-term, large-scale strategies to restore forests, reduce wildfire threats, and utilize available biomass.
• Overall, the federal government has increased funding and efforts to address the growing threat of severe wildfires, but challenges remain in containing costs, reducing fuel loads, and determining the appropriate federal role in fire protection and post-fire rehabilitation.
</summary>

<summary>
• Across the United States, about 27.5% of state and local government employees (about 6.6 million persons) work in positions that are not covered by Social Security. Coverage rates vary considerably across the states, with some states having less than 5% of their state and local government employees covered by Social Security.

• Mandatory Social Security coverage of newly hired state and local government employees has been recommended by recent deficit reduction groups, such as the Bipartisan Policy Center's Debt Reduction Task Force and the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform. This proposal aims to increase the universality of the Social Security program and mitigate potential risks for state and local pension plans.

• Supporters of mandatory coverage argue that it could result in better benefit protections for workers and their families, such as dependents' and survivors' benefits, as well as full cost-of-living adjustments. However, opponents argue that states and localities could reduce existing pension benefits to keep overall costs down.

• Mandatory Social Security coverage would eventually eliminate the need for the Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) and the Government Pension Offset (GPO), which are unpopular provisions of Social Security law that present administrative difficulties for the Social Security Administration.

• Opponents argue that mandatory coverage could impose significant administrative burdens on state and local governments, as they would need to administer two different systems, and that it could raise constitutional issues and be challenged in court.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Trade Adjustment Assistance for Workers (TAA) program provides federal assistance to workers who involuntarily lose their jobs due to foreign competition. It offers funding for training, reemployment services, and income support while a worker is enrolled in training.
* TAA is jointly administered by the federal government and the states, with the U.S. Department of Labor making group eligibility determinations and allotting funds to the states. The program is funded by mandatory appropriations and is subject to sequestration.
* To be eligible for TAA, a group of workers must establish that foreign trade contributed importantly to their job loss. Individual workers then apply for state-administered benefits at local American Job Centers.
* TAA benefits include training and reemployment services, income support, and wage insurance for workers age 50 and over. The program also provides a tax credit for a portion of qualified health insurance premiums.
* The TAA program has been reauthorized several times, with the most recent reauthorization in 2015 through the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act (TAARA). TAARA reinstated many of the eligibility and benefit provisions that were in place prior to 2014.
* The TAARA provisions are authorized to continue through June 30, 2021, after which the program is scheduled to revert to a more limited set of eligibility and benefit provisions, similar to the Reversion 2014 provisions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP) was established in 2004 to provide supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, members of Congress, annuitants, and their dependents. Enrollees are responsible for 100% of the premiums, and the program offers a variety of nationwide and regional dental and vision plans with varying coverage and costs.
* Factors to consider when deciding whether to enroll in FEDVIP include the coverage provided by the individual's Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) plan, the likelihood of using the services covered by FEDVIP, and the option to contribute to a Flexible Spending Account (FSA) for dental and vision expenses.
</summary>

<summary>
* The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA) provided $17.15 billion in supplemental funding for biomedical research, public health, and other health-related programs within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
* ARRA included new authorizing language to promote the widespread adoption of electronic health records and other health information technology, and established a federal interagency advisory panel to coordinate comparative effectiveness research.
* ARRA provided $2 billion to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) for grants to health centers, including $1.5 billion for infrastructure and $500 million for operations.
* ARRA provided $500 million to HRSA for health workforce programs, including the National Health Service Corps and Title VII and Title VIII programs.
* ARRA provided $10.4 billion to the National Institutes of Health (NIH) for biomedical research and extramural research facilities, and $1.1 billion to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) for comparative effectiveness research.
* ARRA provided $2 billion to the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC) to fund activities and grant programs authorized by the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act.
* ARRA provided $1 billion to the Secretary for a Prevention and Wellness Fund, with $300 million for immunization grants, $50 million for reducing healthcare-associated infections, and $650 million for evidence-based prevention and wellness programs.
* ARRA provided $500 million to the Indian Health Service (IHS) for health facilities-related activities and health information technology.
* ARRA required transparency and accountability measures, including implementation plans, reporting requirements, and public tracking of ARRA spending.
* ARRA funds were designated as emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2009, with most funds to remain available for obligation through the end of FY2010.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) requires meat packers to report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). The law was first enacted in 1999 and has been reauthorized several times, most recently in 2015 until September 30, 2020.
• Before LMR, the USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) collected livestock and meat price and related market information from meat packers on a voluntary basis. The goal was to provide all buyers and sellers with accurate and objective market information.
• The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act of 1999 mandated price reporting for live cattle, boxed beef, and live swine and allowed USDA to establish mandatory price reporting for lamb sales. The law authorized appropriations as necessary and required USDA to implement regulations no later than 180 days after the law was enacted.
• The 2015 reauthorization of LMR made several changes, including the addition of a new reporting category for swine, revisions to definitions for lamb importers and packers, and a requirement for USDA to conduct a study of the price-reporting program for cattle, swine, and lamb.
• During the nearly 15 years that LMR has been in place, livestock producers, processors, and industry analysts have come to rely on the AMS mandatory price reporting data to make marketing decisions. Many livestock contracts between buyers and sellers are based on prices reported under LMR.
• The 2015 reauthorization did not include a provision that would have deemed mandatory reporting an "essential" service, which was widely supported by the cattle, swine, and lamb industries to avoid the loss of livestock price information during government shutdowns.
• The new reporting category for swine, called negotiated formula purchase, was proposed by the National Pork Producers Council to better reflect the true measure of price discovery in the hog market.
• The sheep and lamb industry proposed changes to the reporting thresholds for lamb importers and packers to capture pricing data from a larger share of the total lamb market and better reflect average prices.
• The cattle industry did not formally propose any changes to cattle LMR requirements

<summary>
* If a sitting United States Senator is indicted for a criminal offense that constitutes a felony, the status and service of that Member is not directly affected by any federal statute, constitutional provision, or Rule of the Senate.
* Members of Congress do not automatically forfeit their offices even upon conviction of a crime that constitutes a felony, except for certain treasonous conduct after having taken an oath of office.
* Conviction of certain crimes may subject Senators to internal legislative disciplinary proceedings, including resolutions of censure, as well as expulsion from the Senate upon approval of two-thirds of the Members.
* Indictment and/or conviction of a crime that is a felony does not constitutionally disqualify one from being a Member of Congress, as the qualifications are set out in the United States Constitution.
* No law or Rule exists providing that a Member of the Senate who is indicted for or convicted of a crime must forfeit his or her congressional salary.
* Officers and employees of the United States, including Members of Congress, may forfeit their federal pensions upon conviction of certain national security offenses or public corruption-related felonies.
</summary>

<summary>
* The United States has approximately 766 million acres of forestlands, with 58% being privately owned. The federal government has numerous programs to support forest management on both private and public forests, primarily administered by the Forest Service (FS) in the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).
* Forestry assistance programs have been a component of USDA's programs for more than a century, with the FS having three primary mission areas: managing the National Forest System, conducting forestry research, and providing forestry assistance.
* The Senate and House Agriculture Committees have jurisdiction over forestry assistance programs, which are often examined in the periodic omnibus legislation known as farm bills. The 2008 and 2014 farm bills have made various changes to these programs.
* To be eligible for most forestry assistance programs, each state must prepare a State Forest Action Plan and have a State Forest Stewardship Coordination Committee. The programs may provide technical assistance, financial assistance, or both.
* Funding for forestry assistance programs has declined over the past 15 years, both in real and constant dollars, making up about 7% of the FS's total annual discretionary appropriation on average.
* The Administration has requested $197.4 million for these programs in FY2019, proposing to eliminate funding for seven programs and decrease funding for the others.
* Some FS programs have been repealed by previous farm bills or have gone unfunded by Congress for several years, but some of their activities may continue to be performed or provided by FS through other authorizations or funding sources.
</summary>

<summary>
* Transnational organized crime groups flourish in Burma, trafficking a wide range of contraband. Corruption among officials in Burma's ruling military junta facilitates this criminal activity and provides immunity from law enforcement.

* Burma's long borders and difficult-to-control terrain, as well as continuing ethnic tensions, contribute to the prevalence of "ungoverned spaces" that enable transnational crime. The United States has imposed sanctions on Burma in response to its involvement in criminal activities.

* Burma is a major producer of illicit drugs, including opium, heroin, and methamphetamine. Opium production has declined in recent years, but the trade has shifted to other areas and ethnic groups, and the production of synthetic drugs has increased.

* Burma is a source country for human trafficking, with women and girls, especially from ethnic minority groups, being trafficked for sexual exploitation. The government is directly involved in trafficking for forced labor and the recruitment of child soldiers.

* Illegal logging, wildlife trafficking, and the smuggling of gems and other natural resources are also major criminal enterprises in Burma. These activities are often linked to corruption and patronage systems within the government.

* Burma's weak anti-money laundering controls and the use of informal money transfer networks have made the country a hub for money laundering, including the laundering of proceeds from drug trafficking and other illicit activities.

* The United States has taken various actions to address transnational crime in Burma, including sanctions, counter-narcotics assistance, and efforts to combat human trafficking. However, the effectiveness of these policies has been limited by various factors.

* Neighboring countries, such as China and Thailand, are major destinations for contraband from Burma, and the United States is working with these countries to address the regional impact of transnational crime emanating from Burma.

* Despite some progress, such as a reduction in opium cultivation, most experts believe that U.S. policies have not yielded substantial leverage in combating the widespread transnational crime in Burma.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Affordable Care Act (ACA) has had a significant impact on federal mandatory spending, primarily through the expansion of health insurance coverage. This includes premium tax credits, cost-sharing reduction payments, and federal matching funds for states that expanded Medicaid.
* The ACA also appropriated significant amounts to support various new and existing programs, such as the Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan, the Consumer Operated and Oriented Plan, and the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation. It also established several special funds, including the Community Health Center Fund, the Prevention and Public Health Fund, and the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Trust Fund.
* While most of the ACA's appropriations were temporary, Congress has extended funding for several programs, and has also partially reduced or rescinded funding for some initiatives. The ACA's mandatory spending is generally subject to sequestration, with some exceptions, as a result of the Budget Control Act of 2011.
</summary>

<summary>
• The increased presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and in the scientific workforce has been a concern to some in the scientific community. Enrollment of U.S. citizens in these programs has not kept pace with that of foreign students, and a significant number of university faculty in the scientific disciplines are also foreign.
• Foreign students have been using U.S. graduate education programs as stepping stones to immigration, with approximately 56% of foreign doctorate degree earners on temporary visas remaining in the United States and eventually becoming citizens. This has led to charges that U.S. workers are adversely affected by the entry of foreign scientists and engineers, who reportedly accept lower wages.
• The scientific community has been divided over proposals to impose stricter immigration limits on people with scientific and technical skills. While some argue that U.S. universities and industry benefit from the presence of foreign talent, others contend that there is a disparity in access to graduate education and resources for minority students in the United States.
• The debate on the presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and the workforce has intensified following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. Concerns have been expressed about certain foreign students receiving education and training in sensitive areas, and there has been increased discussion about the access of foreign scientists and engineers to research and development related to chemical and biological weapons.
• Comprehensive immigration reform legislation has been debated and introduced in the U.S. Congress, with some bills aimed at attracting foreign students in the scientific and technical disciplines while maintaining the interests of American scientists. The issue of tracking foreign students attending U.S. institutions has also generated particular debate in the academic and scientific community.
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) supports research, development, and deployment of renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies.
• The Trump Administration's FY2018 budget request would significantly reduce EERE funding by nearly 70%.
• The House and Senate appropriations bills would provide more funding for EERE than the Administration's request, with the Senate bill providing the highest level of funding.
• The House and Senate bills would continue to support later-stage research, development, and deployment activities that the Administration's request would terminate.
• The House and Senate bills would continue funding for the Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program, which the Administration's request would eliminate.
• The House bill reflects a "gradual shift towards early stage research and development activities," while the Senate bill affirms the importance of both development and deployment of energy technologies.
• The House and Senate bills would provide increased funding for sustainable transportation, renewable energy, and energy efficiency programs compared to the Administration's request.
• The House and Senate bills would support continued research, development, and deployment of various renewable energy technologies, including solar, wind, water, and geothermal.
• The House and Senate bills would provide increased funding for energy efficiency programs, including advanced manufacturing, building technologies, and federal energy management.
</summary>

<summary>
* Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies that use blockchain technology to validate transactions without a centralized intermediary. They were created in 2008 by an unknown programmer or group of programmers using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto.
* Cryptocurrencies have the potential to provide benefits such as reduced costs for electronic payments, increased privacy, and independence from centralized institutions. However, they also face challenges to widespread adoption, including price volatility, scalability issues, and lack of consumer protections.
* Policymakers are grappling with issues related to cryptocurrencies, such as their potential use in criminal activities, the adequacy of consumer protections, and the appropriate level of regulation. The future role and value of cryptocurrencies remain highly uncertain.

* The invention and growth of cryptocurrencies have raised concerns about their potential impact on monetary policy. Some central banks are exploring the possibility of issuing their own central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), which could provide benefits but also raise challenges.
* Proponents of CBDCs argue they could increase efficiency and stability in the payment system, while critics argue there is no compelling need for them and that they could disrupt private banking and complicate monetary policy.
* The future of cryptocurrencies and CBDCs will depend on technological advancements, economic conditions, and policy decisions. Policymakers will need to carefully consider the potential benefits, challenges, and risks as they navigate this evolving landscape.
* Overall, the emergence of cryptocurrencies and the potential for CBDCs have introduced new complexities and uncertainties into the financial system, which policymakers will need to address in the coming years.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Protecting Employees and Retirees in Business Bankruptcies Act of 2007 (H.R. 3652) proposes several changes to Section 1113 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, which governs the rejection of collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) by companies in Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The bill aims to address the perceived disproportionate burden on employees and retirees during business bankruptcies.
* The proposed changes include limiting the duration of modifications to CBAs, requiring debtors to propose the minimum savings necessary for reorganization, and considering the burden on management personnel when evaluating the fairness of the proposal. The bill also establishes a presumption that the labor group is being overly burdened if the debtor has implemented certain executive compensation programs.
* The bill also introduces new requirements, such as the need for the parties to reach an impasse before the court can approve rejection of a CBA, and grants labor groups the right to strike or engage in other "self-help" measures in response to court-ordered modifications or rejections of CBAs.
</summary>

<summary>
* This report discusses appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2016, focusing on the components included in the first title of the homeland security appropriations bill. These components are collectively known as "Departmental Management and Operations."
* The report provides an overview of the Administration's FY2016 request, the appropriations proposed by Congress, and the final enacted appropriations. It also includes information on provisions throughout the proposed bills and reports that directly affect these functions.

* The Departmental Management and Operations components made up about 3% of the discretionary appropriations requested for DHS for FY2016. The enacted appropriations for these components in FY2016 were $1,546 million, $150 million (10.7%) more than requested.
* The report discusses funding for the Office of the Secretary and Executive Management, the Under Secretary for Management, the Office of the Chief Financial Officer, the Office of the Chief Information Officer, and other management functions.

* The Administration requested $702 million for departmental management, plus $43 million for a financial systems consolidation effort. The enacted appropriations provided $701 million for departmental management and $203 million for other provisions, including $150 million to address emergent threats and support cybersecurity efforts.
* The report discusses issues related to acquisition matters and the implementation of a common appropriations structure, which were related to the department's Unity of Effort initiative.

* The report also discusses the DHS headquarters consolidation project, which was requested at $204 million for DHS and $380 million for the General Services Administration (GSA) in FY2016. The enacted appropriations provided $216 million for the project.
* The Analysis and Operations account, which includes resources for the Office of Intelligence and Analysis and the Office of Operations Coordination, was requested at $269 million and enacted at $265 million.

* The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) was requested at $142 million in appropriations and $24 million in transfers from the Disaster Relief Fund. The enacted appropriations provided $137 million in appropriations and the requested transfer.
* The report discusses issues surrounding the DHS OIG, which are generally issues that impact the broader oversight community or are shared throughout the broader community of inspectors general.
</summary>

<summary>
• Gross job loss and gross job gains are much larger than net job loss, and are a normal part of a functioning market economy. Gross job loss is caused by factors like trade, outsourcing, and economic restructuring, but these typically do not cause net job loss.

• Net job loss is a serious economic problem that can be mitigated by fiscal and monetary policy. However, policies that impede gross job loss can have high efficiency costs and reduce gross job gains, making them ultimately self-defeating.

• Public policies to protect workers against the risks posed by gross job loss can be justified on both social and economic grounds, as they can address market failures in the private insurance market.

• The challenge for policymakers is to find the right balance between mitigating risk and maintaining market dynamism in an increasingly fluid labor market.
</summary>

<summary>
* Shinzo Abe has been Japan's prime minister since 2012 and is expected to become the longest-serving prime minister in modern Japanese history. Abe's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) maintains a firm grip on power, with the LDP and its coalition partner Komeito controlling Japan's legislature.

* The U.S.-Japan alliance remains a key pillar of U.S. strategy in Asia, with the U.S. providing security guarantees and Japan hosting a significant U.S. military presence. However, tensions have emerged over trade and North Korea policy, raising questions about the durability of the alliance.

* Japan's economy has struggled with stagnation and deflation for decades, prompting Abe to launch his "Abenomics" program of monetary, fiscal, and structural reforms. While progress has been uneven, the economy has shown signs of improvement in recent years.

* Historical issues, particularly related to Japan's wartime actions, continue to strain Japan's relationships with its neighbors, China and South Korea. Abe has sought to improve ties with China, but tensions with South Korea remain high.

* The Trump administration has imposed tariffs on certain Japanese exports, raising tensions in the economic relationship. The two countries have announced plans to begin new bilateral trade negotiations, though the scope and ambition of the talks remain unclear.

* Japan's security policy has evolved, with Abe pushing for a more active role for the Japan Self-Defense Forces, including the potential for collective self-defense. This has drawn criticism from Japan's neighbors and some domestic opposition.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Homeland Security's Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is responsible for the medical care of noncitizens in its custody, which is outlined in the National Detention Standards.
* ICE contracts with various companies to inspect and oversee the detention facilities, but concerns have been raised about the effectiveness of this oversight.
* The Division of Immigrant Health Services (DIHS) is responsible for providing health care to detainees, but the scope of services is limited to emergency and urgent care.
* Detainees must submit a Treatment Authorization Request (TAR) for non-emergency care, which is reviewed by DIHS nurses, and there are concerns about the timeliness and adequacy of this process.
* Reports have highlighted issues with detainees' access to medical care, including delays in receiving treatment and difficulties obtaining certain procedures like biopsies.
* The appropriate standard of health care for detainees is debated, as some argue they receive better care than they would in their home countries, while others contend the care is inadequate.
* Concerns have been raised about the oversight and reporting of detainee deaths, and the use of mortality rates as a measure of the quality of care.
* Legislation has been introduced to establish procedures for the timely and effective delivery of medical and mental health care to immigration detainees.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Millennium Challenge Account (MCA) is a new U.S. foreign aid initiative that aims to provide increased economic assistance to countries that demonstrate a commitment to good governance, economic freedom, and investment in people. The MCA is managed by a new government entity, the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC), which is overseen by a Board of Directors chaired by the Secretary of State.

• The MCA uses a set of 16 performance indicators to select eligible countries, with a focus on "best performers" that score above the median on at least half of the indicators in each policy area. The selection process is designed to be transparent and results-oriented, with a goal of maximizing the impact of U.S. aid resources.

• The MCA is intended to be an additional source of foreign aid, not a replacement for existing programs. However, the creation of the MCA has raised concerns about its impact on other U.S. development assistance efforts, including the role of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).

• Congress has played a key role in shaping the MCA, including issues related to country eligibility, performance indicators, organizational structure, and funding levels. The MCA has been the subject of ongoing debate and oversight as the initiative is implemented.
</summary>

<summary>
* The 112th Congress is considering an omnibus farm bill that will establish the direction of agricultural policy for the next several years. The Senate-passed farm bill (S. 3240) would reduce spending by $23.1 billion, while the House Agriculture Committee-reported bill (H.R. 6083) would reduce it by $35.1 billion.
* The bills make significant changes to farm commodity support, crop insurance, conservation programs, the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), and other areas. The bills also include provisions related to trade, rural development, research, forestry, energy, horticulture, and miscellaneous topics.
</summary>

<summary>
• Inland waterways are a significant component of the nation's transportation system, carrying approximately one-sixth of the national volume of intercity cargo. The federal government invests in inland waterways due to their value to the nation, with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers responsible for developing, operating, and maintaining the infrastructure.

• The current financing system for inland waterways was established in the 1970s and 1980s, with a fuel tax on commercial barges and cost-sharing requirements for construction projects. However, the revenue from the fuel tax is insufficient to cover the costs, leading to proposals to change the financing system.

• The Bush and Obama administrations have proposed new user fees to replace or supplement the fuel tax, but these proposals have been rejected by Congress. The Inland Waterways Users Board has proposed increasing the fuel tax and shifting more of the costs to the federal government.

• Congress faces several issues in addressing the financing of inland waterways, including the level of investment needed, the structure of user fees, and the cost-sharing arrangements between the federal government and commercial users.
</summary>

<summary>
• Congress has used commemoratives to express public gratitude, dramatize virtues, and perpetuate the remembrance of significant events. Over the years, Congress has taken steps to reduce the number of commemoratives proposed through legislation, such as creating an advisory commission and amending congressional rules.
• Congress has various legislative options for commemorations, including naming federal buildings, designing postage stamps, minting commemorative coins, awarding Congressional Gold Medals, creating monuments and memorials, designating commemorative observances, establishing federal holidays, and requesting presidential proclamations. Additionally, Congress has nonlegislative options such as sending certificates of recognition, making floor speeches, and ordering flags.
</summary>

<summary>
• The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 (COMPETES 2010) was designed to invest in innovation through research and development and improve the competitiveness of the United States.
• COMPETES 2010 authorized approximately $45.5 billion in funding between FY2010 and FY2013 for federal research in the physical sciences and engineering, STEM education, and other related programs.
• The President's FY2013 budget request sought increases over FY2012 levels for many key COMPETES 2010 accounts, but the combined effects of sequestration and rescissions decreased funding levels for many of these accounts below FY2010 actual levels.
• The gap between COMPETES act authorizations and appropriations widened in FY2013 and was larger than in all previous authorized years.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Lacey Act was enacted in 1900 to address game poaching and wildlife laundering. The 2008 amendments expanded the act to include nonindigenous plants and violations of foreign laws pertaining to certain conservation actions and other activities involving plants and plant products.
* The primary aims of the 2008 amendments were to reduce illegal logging and increase the value of U.S. wood exports. Illegal logging is a pervasive problem affecting several countries that produce, export, and import wood and wood products.
* The 2008 amendments require importers of all covered plants and plant products to submit an import declaration to U.S. Customs and Border Protection at the time of importation. The declaration must contain information such as the identification of the species and genus of plants or plants used in a product, and the country of origin of plants.

* Some question why U.S. importers should be held responsible for violations of foreign law potentially committed by foreign entities. They claim it is difficult to monitor the harvesting and processing of plants and plant products in foreign countries to ensure no foreign laws are being violated.
* Several businesses have suggested that the declaration requirements for importing plants and plant products are cumbersome and, in some cases, not possible to meet. Identifying the species and genus of wood products and filling out paperwork for declarations could require additional staff for companies importing wood and wood products.
* The Lacey Act can be enforced at the border or through investigations. Agents at ports of entry inspect imports and monitor the declaration process, and inspectors can initiate and conduct investigations into violations of the Lacey Act.

* Several policy issues are associated with the 2008 amendments, ranging from questions about the overall purpose and function of the Lacey Act to issues about specific provisions in the act such as the declaration requirements.
* The enactment and implementation of the 2008 amendments has led some to contend that the law increases costs for certain companies and could result in the loss of jobs. Others, in contrast, contend that the law increases revenue for certain companies and thus could lead to job creation.
* Regulatory changes to the declaration requirements under the Lacey Act can be implemented from recommendations provided by certain reports and reviews. The Secretary is authorized to promulgate regulations that could modify certain declaration requirements for plant products 180 days after the Secretary completes the review

<summary>
* The farm economy is often characterized as cyclical, with exaggerated price swings that are destabilizing. Farmers respond to high prices by boosting output, but are not quick to cut back production when prices drop.
* Between 1973 and 1995, a prominent form of counter-cyclical aid was deficiency payments linked to target prices. The 1996 Farm Bill replaced target price deficiency payments with fixed production flexibility contract (PFC) payments.
* The 1996 Farm Bill continued another form of counter-cyclical support: marketing assistance loans. Producers could pledge their stored grain, cotton, or oilseeds as collateral for a USDA nonrecourse commodity loan after harvest.
* By the late 1990s, major commodity prices declined even more than expected, and Congress determined that the "safety net" provided by the 1996 FAIR Act was inadequate, and supplemented the benefits with additional, emergency "market loss payments."

* The 2002 Farm Security and Rural Investment Act (FSRIA) provides new long-term counter-cyclical support for grains and cotton, by restoring target prices and deficiency payments, similar in some respects to the program terminated by the 1996 Act.
* Under the new law, fixed payments and target price deficiency payments will be paid on 85% of each farm's base production. The new counter-cyclical program will be decoupled from current output, but the target price deficiency payments will be tied to current market prices.
* The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has estimated the commodity support provisions of FSRIA at $98.9 billion over 6 years, with the new counter-cyclical payments for grains, cotton, and oilseeds accounting for $23.6 billion of the new costs.
* The 1994 Uruguay Round Agreement on Agriculture (URAA) obligates countries to discipline their agricultural subsidy programs and reduce import barriers in order to promote more open trade.

* The new counter-cyclical aid in the 2002 law focuses on the "major" commodities -- grains, cotton, oilseeds, peanuts, and milk. This leaves much of U.S. agriculture ineligible for such payments, raising questions of equity among commodities.
* Another issue was whether

<summary>
• The United States and Vietnam established a civilian nuclear cooperation agreement in 2014 under Section 123 of the Atomic Energy Act. This agreement was subject to congressional review, during which several issues were debated, including Vietnam's nonproliferation commitments, human rights record, and the strategic relationship between the two countries.
• Vietnam's nuclear energy plans include building its first nuclear power plants, with the first two reactors expected to come online by the mid-2020s. Russia and Japan are the primary partners for these projects, but the U.S. nuclear industry may also have a role, which would be facilitated by the 123 agreement.
• Vietnam has taken steps to strengthen its nuclear safety and regulatory framework, with assistance from the IAEA and the U.S. government. However, concerns have been raised about Vietnam's capacity to safely operate nuclear power plants, particularly in light of the Fukushima disaster.
• Vietnam has a strong record of supporting nuclear nonproliferation and has joined various international initiatives. The 123 agreement includes provisions to prevent the enrichment or reprocessing of U.S.-obligated nuclear materials without specific U.S. consent.
• The U.S.-Vietnam nuclear cooperation agreement is seen as part of the broader strengthening of the bilateral relationship, which has been driven by overlapping strategic and economic interests, including concerns over China's regional influence.
• Differences over Vietnam's human rights record have been a persistent challenge in the U.S.-Vietnam relationship, and some members of Congress have called for linking the 123 agreement to progress on human rights. However, these differences have not prevented the two countries from expanding cooperation in other areas.
</summary>

<summary>
• The report provides a chronology of events related to U.S. relations with North Korea in 2005. It highlights key developments, including North Korea's announcement of its nuclear weapons program, the Six-Party Talks, and changes in U.S. officials overseeing North Korean policy.
• North Korea escalated tensions in early 2005 by announcing its possession of nuclear weapons and suspending participation in the Six-Party Talks. However, a joint statement issued in September 2005 was seen as a breakthrough, though it was short-lived.
• The report discusses the increased focus on North Korea's human rights record and criminal activities, as well as the strained relations between the U.S. and South Korea over their approaches to the North Korean issue.
• China's role as the host and broker of the Six-Party Talks is highlighted, with its strategy of balancing its interests with both Koreas and enhancing its diplomatic influence.
• Japan's relations with its neighbors deteriorated due to historical disputes and the conservative shift in its leadership, which affected its efforts to normalize ties with North Korea.
• Non-administration officials and specialists continued to visit North Korea, with some conveying messages about the country's nuclear program and its willingness to rejoin the Six-Party Talks.
• The report provides a list of related CRS reports that offer additional information on various aspects of U.S. relations with North Korea.
• The chronology covers significant meetings, events, and statements that shed light on the issues surrounding North Korea's nuclear weapons program.
• The year 2005 saw little progress in resolving the North Korean nuclear issue, with adjustments in U.S. officials and the addition of new agenda items, but no major breakthroughs.
• The report serves as a continuation of a previous CRS report on North Korea, providing a comprehensive overview of the events and dynamics in 2005.
</summary>

<summary>
* Protein separation techniques and mass spectrometry have improved, enabling qualitative and quantitative proteome comparisons.
* Comprehensive protein profiles from complex samples remain challenging due to the large number of proteins present over wide concentration ranges.
* The study compared a conventional gelc-MS/MS method, gelc-MS/MS with repetitive injections, and a 3-D method using microscale solution isoelectrofocusing (microSOLIEF) prior to SDS-PAGE.
* The 3-D method identified 22% more proteins with two or more peptides compared to the 2-D/repetitive method using equal instrument time.
* The 3-D method also identified 28% more unique peptides than the cumulative 2-D method data.
* The 3-D method provided superior protein and peptide coverage by reducing ion suppression and dynamic range within each digest.
* Repetitive analysis improved proteome coverage but lacked mechanisms to reduce repeated sampling of abundant ions between replicates.
* The reproducibility of protein lists between the two methods was high, with over 90% of the proteins observed in the 2-D/four-replicate data set matching the 3-D data set.
* Apparent differences in protein identifications were due to limitations of current sequence databases and protein naming conventions, as well as software limitations.
* Additional prefractionation with microSOLIEF substantially increased proteome coverage and sequence coverage compared to the gelc-MS/MS-repetitive run method.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study compared the incidence of secondary, delayed postoperative hemorrhage between tonsillectomy and submucosal uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (SMUPPP) procedures. The incidence of delayed hemorrhage was significantly lower in the SMUPPP group compared to the tonsillectomy group.

• The study suggests that suturing both the muscular and mucosal layers of the tonsillar fossa in SMUPPP, as well as bipolar cauterization followed by tacking with sutures, may have contributed to the decreased incidence of postoperative bleeding.

• The authors recommend the routine use of the suturing technique for SMUPPP in all tonsillectomy patients to reduce the rate of postoperative hemorrhage.
</summary>

<summary>
* The α- and β-lactam scaffolds are found in various biologically relevant compounds and are crucial intermediates in the synthesis of natural products and pharmaceuticals.
* The authors have explored the synthesis of β-lactams by the reactions of aryl-, thioaryl-, and cyano-substituted anhydrides, and have demonstrated that one-pot four-component reactions are possible in the case of thioaryl substitution.
